2103                 ret = migrate_task_to(p, env.best_cpu);
2104                 WRITE_ONCE(best_rq->numa_migrate_on, 0);
2105                 if (ret != 0)
2106                         trace_sched_stick_numa(p, env.src_cpu, NULL, env.best_cpu);
2107                 return ret;
2108         }
2109 
2110         ret = migrate_swap(p, env.best_task, env.best_cpu, env.src_cpu);
2111         WRITE_ONCE(best_rq->numa_migrate_on, 0);
2112 
2113         if (ret != 0)
2114                 trace_sched_stick_numa(p, env.src_cpu, env.best_task, env.best_cpu);
2115         put_task_struct(env.best_task);
2116         return ret;
2117 }
2118 
2119 /* Attempt to migrate a task to a CPU on the preferred node. */
2120 static void numa_migrate_preferred(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
2121 {
2122         unsigned long interval = HZ;
2123 
2124         /* This task has no NUMA fault statistics yet */
2125         if (unlikely(p->numa_preferred_nid == NUMA_NO_NODE || !p->numa_faults))
2126                 return;
2127 
2128         /* Periodically retry migrating the task to the preferred node */
2129         interval = min(interval, msecs_to_jiffies(p->numa_scan_period) / 16);
2130         p->numa_migrate_retry = jiffies + interval;
2131 
2132         /* Success if task is already running on preferred CPU */
2133         if (task_node(p) == p->numa_preferred_nid)
2134                 return;
2135 
2136         /* Otherwise, try migrate to a CPU on the preferred node */
2137         task_numa_migrate(p);
2138 }
2139 
2140 /*
2141  * Find out how many nodes on the workload is actively running on. Do this by
2142  * tracking the nodes from which NUMA hinting faults are triggered. This can
2143  * be different from the set of nodes where the workload's memory is currently
2144  * located.
2145  */
2146 static void numa_group_count_active_nodes(struct numa_group *numa_group)
     /*   */
2147 {
2148         unsigned long faults, max_faults = 0;
2149         int nid, active_nodes = 0;
2150 
2151         for_each_online_node(nid) {
2152                 faults = group_faults_cpu(numa_group, nid);
2153                 if (faults > max_faults)
2154                         max_faults = faults;
2155         }
2156 
2157         for_each_online_node(nid) {
2158                 faults = group_faults_cpu(numa_group, nid);
2159                 if (faults * ACTIVE_NODE_FRACTION > max_faults)
2160                         active_nodes++;
2161         }
2162 
2163         numa_group->max_faults_cpu = max_faults;
2164         numa_group->active_nodes = active_nodes;
2165 }
2166 
2167 /*
2168  * When adapting the scan rate, the period is divided into NUMA_PERIOD_SLOTS
2169  * increments. The more local the fault statistics are, the higher the scan
2170  * period will be for the next scan window. If local/(local+remote) ratio is
2171  * below NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD (where range of ratio is 1..NUMA_PERIOD_SLOTS)
2172  * the scan period will decrease. Aim for 70% local accesses.
2173  */
2174 #define NUMA_PERIOD_SLOTS 10
2175 #define NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD 7
2176 
2177 /*
2178  * Increase the scan period (slow down scanning) if the majority of
2179  * our memory is already on our local node, or if the majority of
2180  * the page accesses are shared with other processes.
2181  * Otherwise, decrease the scan period.
2182  */
2183 static void update_task_scan_period(struct task_struct *p,
     /*   */
2184                         unsigned long shared, unsigned long private)
2185 {
2186         unsigned int period_slot;
2187         int lr_ratio, ps_ratio;
2188         int diff;
2189 
2190         unsigned long remote = p->numa_faults_locality[0];
2191         unsigned long local = p->numa_faults_locality[1];
2192 
2193         /*
2194          * If there were no record hinting faults then either the task is
2195          * completely idle or all activity is areas that are not of interest
2196          * to automatic numa balancing. Related to that, if there were failed
2197          * migration then it implies we are migrating too quickly or the local
2198          * node is overloaded. In either case, scan slower
2199          */
2200         if (local + shared == 0 || p->numa_faults_locality[2]) {
2201                 p->numa_scan_period = min(p->numa_scan_period_max,
2202                         p->numa_scan_period << 1);
2203 
2204                 p->mm->numa_next_scan = jiffies +
2205                         msecs_to_jiffies(p->numa_scan_period);
2206 
2207                 return;
2208         }
2209 
2210         /*
2211          * Prepare to scale scan period relative to the current period.
2212          *       == NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD scan period stays the same
2213          *       <  NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD scan period decreases (scan faster)
2214          *       >= NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD scan period increases (scan slower)
2215          */
2216         period_slot = DIV_ROUND_UP(p->numa_scan_period, NUMA_PERIOD_SLOTS);
2217         lr_ratio = (local * NUMA_PERIOD_SLOTS) / (local + remote);
2218         ps_ratio = (private * NUMA_PERIOD_SLOTS) / (private + shared);
2219 
2220         if (ps_ratio >= NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD) {
2221                 /*
2222                  * Most memory accesses are local. There is no need to
2223                  * do fast NUMA scanning, since memory is already local.
2224                  */
2225                 int slot = ps_ratio - NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD;
2226                 if (!slot)
2227                         slot = 1;
2228                 diff = slot * period_slot;
2229         } else if (lr_ratio >= NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD) {
2230                 /*
2231                  * Most memory accesses are shared with other tasks.
2232                  * There is no point in continuing fast NUMA scanning,
2233                  * since other tasks may just move the memory elsewhere.
2234                  */
2235                 int slot = lr_ratio - NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD;
2236                 if (!slot)
2237                         slot = 1;
2238                 diff = slot * period_slot;
2239         } else {
2240                 /*
2241                  * Private memory faults exceed (SLOTS-THRESHOLD)/SLOTS,
2242                  * yet they are not on the local NUMA node. Speed up
2243                  * NUMA scanning to get the memory moved over.
2244                  */
2245                 int ratio = max(lr_ratio, ps_ratio);
2246                 diff = -(NUMA_PERIOD_THRESHOLD - ratio) * period_slot;
2247         }
2248 
2249         p->numa_scan_period = clamp(p->numa_scan_period + diff,
2250                         task_scan_min(p), task_scan_max(p));
2251         memset(p->numa_faults_locality, 0, sizeof(p->numa_faults_locality));
2252 }
2253 
2254 /*
2255  * Get the fraction of time the task has been running since the last
2256  * NUMA placement cycle. The scheduler keeps similar statistics, but
2257  * decays those on a 32ms period, which is orders of magnitude off
2258  * from the dozens-of-seconds NUMA balancing period. Use the scheduler
2259  * stats only if the task is so new there are no NUMA statistics yet.
2260  */
2261 static u64 numa_get_avg_runtime(struct task_struct *p, u64 *period)
     /*   */
2262 {
2263         u64 runtime, delta, now;
2264         /* Use the start of this time slice to avoid calculations. */
2265         now = p->se.exec_start;
2266         runtime = p->se.sum_exec_runtime;
2267 
2268         if (p->last_task_numa_placement) {
2269                 delta = runtime - p->last_sum_exec_runtime;
2270                 *period = now - p->last_task_numa_placement;
2271 
2272                 /* Avoid time going backwards, prevent potential divide error: */
2273                 if (unlikely((s64)*period < 0))
2274                         *period = 0;
2275         } else {
2276                 delta = p->se.avg.load_sum;
2277                 *period = LOAD_AVG_MAX;
2278         }
2279 
2280         p->last_sum_exec_runtime = runtime;
2281         p->last_task_numa_placement = now;
2282 
2283         return delta;
2284 }
2285 
2286 /*
2287  * Determine the preferred nid for a task in a numa_group. This needs to
2288  * be done in a way that produces consistent results with group_weight,
2289  * otherwise workloads might not converge.
2290  */
2291 static int preferred_group_nid(struct task_struct *p, int nid)
     /*   */
2292 {
2293         nodemask_t nodes;
2294         int dist;
2295 
2296         /* Direct connections between all NUMA nodes. */
2297         if (sched_numa_topology_type == NUMA_DIRECT)
2298                 return nid;
2299 
2300         /*
2301          * On a system with glueless mesh NUMA topology, group_weight
2302          * scores nodes according to the number of NUMA hinting faults on
2303          * both the node itself, and on nearby nodes.
2304          */
2305         if (sched_numa_topology_type == NUMA_GLUELESS_MESH) {
2306                 unsigned long score, max_score = 0;
2307                 int node, max_node = nid;
2308 
2309                 dist = sched_max_numa_distance;
2310 
2311                 for_each_online_node(node) {
2312                         score = group_weight(p, node, dist);
2313                         if (score > max_score) {
2314                                 max_score = score;
2315                                 max_node = node;
2316                         }
2317                 }
2318                 return max_node;
2319         }
2320 
2321         /*
2322          * Finding the preferred nid in a system with NUMA backplane
2323          * interconnect topology is more involved. The goal is to locate
2324          * tasks from numa_groups near each other in the system, and
2325          * untangle workloads from different sides of the system. This requires
2326          * searching down the hierarchy of node groups, recursively searching
2327          * inside the highest scoring group of nodes. The nodemask tricks
2328          * keep the complexity of the search down.
2329          */
2330         nodes = node_online_map;
2331         for (dist = sched_max_numa_distance; dist > LOCAL_DISTANCE; dist--) {
2332                 unsigned long max_faults = 0;
2333                 nodemask_t max_group = NODE_MASK_NONE;
2334                 int a, b;
2335 
2336                 /* Are there nodes at this distance from each other? */
2337                 if (!find_numa_distance(dist))
2338                         continue;
2339 
2340                 for_each_node_mask(a, nodes) {
2341                         unsigned long faults = 0;
2342                         nodemask_t this_group;
2343                         nodes_clear(this_group);
2344 
2345                         /* Sum group's NUMA faults; includes a==b case. */
2346                         for_each_node_mask(b, nodes) {
2347                                 if (node_distance(a, b) < dist) {
2348                                         faults += group_faults(p, b);
2349                                         node_set(b, this_group);
2350                                         node_clear(b, nodes);
2351                                 }
2352                         }
2353 
2354                         /* Remember the top group. */
2355                         if (faults > max_faults) {
2356                                 max_faults = faults;
2357                                 max_group = this_group;
2358                                 /*
2359                                  * subtle: at the smallest distance there is
2360                                  * just one node left in each "group", the
2361                                  * winner is the preferred nid.
2362                                  */
2363                                 nid = a;
2364                         }
2365                 }
2366                 /* Next round, evaluate the nodes within max_group. */
2367                 if (!max_faults)
2368                         break;
2369                 nodes = max_group;
2370         }
2371         return nid;
2372 }
2373 
2374 static void task_numa_placement(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
2375 {
2376         int seq, nid, max_nid = NUMA_NO_NODE;
2377         unsigned long max_faults = 0;
2378         unsigned long fault_types[2] = { 0, 0 };
2379         unsigned long total_faults;
2380         u64 runtime, period;
2381         spinlock_t *group_lock = NULL;
2382         struct numa_group *ng;
2383 
2384         /*
2385          * The p->mm->numa_scan_seq field gets updated without
2386          * exclusive access. Use READ_ONCE() here to ensure
2387          * that the field is read in a single access:
2388          */
2389         seq = READ_ONCE(p->mm->numa_scan_seq);
2390         if (p->numa_scan_seq == seq)
2391                 return;
2392         p->numa_scan_seq = seq;
2393         p->numa_scan_period_max = task_scan_max(p);
2394 
2395         total_faults = p->numa_faults_locality[0] +
2396                        p->numa_faults_locality[1];
2397         runtime = numa_get_avg_runtime(p, &period);
2398 
2399         /* If the task is part of a group prevent parallel updates to group stats */
2400         ng = deref_curr_numa_group(p);
2401         if (ng) {
2402                 group_lock = &ng->lock;
2403                 spin_lock_irq(group_lock);
2404         }
2405 
2406         /* Find the node with the highest number of faults */
2407         for_each_online_node(nid) {
2408                 /* Keep track of the offsets in numa_faults array */
2409                 int mem_idx, membuf_idx, cpu_idx, cpubuf_idx;
2410                 unsigned long faults = 0, group_faults = 0;
2411                 int priv;
2412 
2413                 for (priv = 0; priv < NR_NUMA_HINT_FAULT_TYPES; priv++) {
2414                         long diff, f_diff, f_weight;
2415 
2416                         mem_idx = task_faults_idx(NUMA_MEM, nid, priv);
2417                         membuf_idx = task_faults_idx(NUMA_MEMBUF, nid, priv);
2418                         cpu_idx = task_faults_idx(NUMA_CPU, nid, priv);
2419                         cpubuf_idx = task_faults_idx(NUMA_CPUBUF, nid, priv);
2420 
2421                         /* Decay existing window, copy faults since last scan */
2422                         diff = p->numa_faults[membuf_idx] - p->numa_faults[mem_idx] / 2;
2423                         fault_types[priv] += p->numa_faults[membuf_idx];
2424                         p->numa_faults[membuf_idx] = 0;
2425 
2426                         /*
2427                          * Normalize the faults_from, so all tasks in a group
2428                          * count according to CPU use, instead of by the raw
2429                          * number of faults. Tasks with little runtime have
2430                          * little over-all impact on throughput, and thus their
2431                          * faults are less important.
2432                          */
2433                         f_weight = div64_u64(runtime << 16, period + 1);
2434                         f_weight = (f_weight * p->numa_faults[cpubuf_idx]) /
2435                                    (total_faults + 1);
2436                         f_diff = f_weight - p->numa_faults[cpu_idx] / 2;
2437                         p->numa_faults[cpubuf_idx] = 0;
2438 
2439                         p->numa_faults[mem_idx] += diff;
2440                         p->numa_faults[cpu_idx] += f_diff;
2441                         faults += p->numa_faults[mem_idx];
2442                         p->total_numa_faults += diff;
2443                         if (ng) {
2444                                 /*
2445                                  * safe because we can only change our own group
2446                                  *
2447                                  * mem_idx represents the offset for a given
2448                                  * nid and priv in a specific region because it
2449                                  * is at the beginning of the numa_faults array.
2450                                  */
2451                                 ng->faults[mem_idx] += diff;
2452                                 ng->faults_cpu[mem_idx] += f_diff;
2453                                 ng->total_faults += diff;
2454                                 group_faults += ng->faults[mem_idx];
2455                         }
2456                 }
2457 
2458                 if (!ng) {
2459                         if (faults > max_faults) {
2460                                 max_faults = faults;
2461                                 max_nid = nid;
2462                         }
2463                 } else if (group_faults > max_faults) {
2464                         max_faults = group_faults;
2465                         max_nid = nid;
2466                 }
2467         }
2468 
2469         if (ng) {
2470                 numa_group_count_active_nodes(ng);
2471                 spin_unlock_irq(group_lock);
2472                 max_nid = preferred_group_nid(p, max_nid);
2473         }
2474 
2475         if (max_faults) {
2476                 /* Set the new preferred node */
2477                 if (max_nid != p->numa_preferred_nid)
2478                         sched_setnuma(p, max_nid);
2479         }
2480 
2481         update_task_scan_period(p, fault_types[0], fault_types[1]);
2482 }
2483 
2484 static inline int get_numa_group(struct numa_group *grp)
     /*   */
2485 {
2486         return refcount_inc_not_zero(&grp->refcount);
2487 }
2488 
2489 static inline void put_numa_group(struct numa_group *grp)
     /*   */
2490 {
2491         if (refcount_dec_and_test(&grp->refcount))
2492                 kfree_rcu(grp, rcu);
2493 }
2494 
2495 static void task_numa_group(struct task_struct *p, int cpupid, int flags,
     /*   */
2496                         int *priv)
2497 {
2498         struct numa_group *grp, *my_grp;
2499         struct task_struct *tsk;
2500         bool join = false;
2501         int cpu = cpupid_to_cpu(cpupid);
2502         int i;
2503 
2504         if (unlikely(!deref_curr_numa_group(p))) {
2505                 unsigned int size = sizeof(struct numa_group) +
2506                                     4*nr_node_ids*sizeof(unsigned long);
2507 
2508                 grp = kzalloc(size, GFP_KERNEL | __GFP_NOWARN);
2509                 if (!grp)
2510                         return;
2511 
2512                 refcount_set(&grp->refcount, 1);
2513                 grp->active_nodes = 1;
2514                 grp->max_faults_cpu = 0;
2515                 spin_lock_init(&grp->lock);
2516                 grp->gid = p->pid;
2517                 /* Second half of the array tracks nids where faults happen */
2518                 grp->faults_cpu = grp->faults + NR_NUMA_HINT_FAULT_TYPES *
2519                                                 nr_node_ids;
2520 
2521                 for (i = 0; i < NR_NUMA_HINT_FAULT_STATS * nr_node_ids; i++)
2522                         grp->faults[i] = p->numa_faults[i];
2523 
2524                 grp->total_faults = p->total_numa_faults;
2525 
2526                 grp->nr_tasks++;
2527                 rcu_assign_pointer(p->numa_group, grp);
2528         }
2529 
2530         rcu_read_lock();
2531         tsk = READ_ONCE(cpu_rq(cpu)->curr);
2532 
2533         if (!cpupid_match_pid(tsk, cpupid))
2534                 goto no_join;
2535 
2536         grp = rcu_dereference(tsk->numa_group);
2537         if (!grp)
2538                 goto no_join;
2539 
2540         my_grp = deref_curr_numa_group(p);
2541         if (grp == my_grp)
2542                 goto no_join;
2543 
2544         /*
2545          * Only join the other group if its bigger; if we're the bigger group,
2546          * the other task will join us.
2547          */
2548         if (my_grp->nr_tasks > grp->nr_tasks)
2549                 goto no_join;
2550 
2551         /*
2552          * Tie-break on the grp address.
2553          */
2554         if (my_grp->nr_tasks == grp->nr_tasks && my_grp > grp)
2555                 goto no_join;
2556 
2557         /* Always join threads in the same process. */
2558         if (tsk->mm == current->mm)
2559                 join = true;
2560 
2561         /* Simple filter to avoid false positives due to PID collisions */
2562         if (flags & TNF_SHARED)
2563                 join = true;
2564 
2565         /* Update priv based on whether false sharing was detected */
2566         *priv = !join;
2567 
2568         if (join && !get_numa_group(grp))
2569                 goto no_join;
2570 
2571         rcu_read_unlock();
2572 
2573         if (!join)
2574                 return;
2575 
2576         BUG_ON(irqs_disabled());
2577         double_lock_irq(&my_grp->lock, &grp->lock);
2578 
2579         for (i = 0; i < NR_NUMA_HINT_FAULT_STATS * nr_node_ids; i++) {
2580                 my_grp->faults[i] -= p->numa_faults[i];
2581                 grp->faults[i] += p->numa_faults[i];
2582         }
2583         my_grp->total_faults -= p->total_numa_faults;
2584         grp->total_faults += p->total_numa_faults;
2585 
2586         my_grp->nr_tasks--;
2587         grp->nr_tasks++;
2588 
2589         spin_unlock(&my_grp->lock);
2590         spin_unlock_irq(&grp->lock);
2591 
2592         rcu_assign_pointer(p->numa_group, grp);
2593 
2594         put_numa_group(my_grp);
2595         return;
2596 
2597 no_join:
2598         rcu_read_unlock();
2599         return;
2600 }
2601 
2602 /*
2603  * Get rid of NUMA staticstics associated with a task (either current or dead).
2604  * If @final is set, the task is dead and has reached refcount zero, so we can
2605  * safely free all relevant data structures. Otherwise, there might be
2606  * concurrent reads from places like load balancing and procfs, and we should
2607  * reset the data back to default state without freeing ->numa_faults.
2608  */
2609 void task_numa_free(struct task_struct *p, bool final)
     /*   */
2610 {
2611         /* safe: p either is current or is being freed by current */
2612         struct numa_group *grp = rcu_dereference_raw(p->numa_group);
2613         unsigned long *numa_faults = p->numa_faults;
2614         unsigned long flags;
2615         int i;
2616 
2617         if (!numa_faults)
2618                 return;
2619 
2620         if (grp) {
2621                 spin_lock_irqsave(&grp->lock, flags);
2622                 for (i = 0; i < NR_NUMA_HINT_FAULT_STATS * nr_node_ids; i++)
2623                         grp->faults[i] -= p->numa_faults[i];
2624                 grp->total_faults -= p->total_numa_faults;
2625 
2626                 grp->nr_tasks--;
2627                 spin_unlock_irqrestore(&grp->lock, flags);
2628                 RCU_INIT_POINTER(p->numa_group, NULL);
2629                 put_numa_group(grp);
2630         }
2631 
2632         if (final) {
2633                 p->numa_faults = NULL;
2634                 kfree(numa_faults);
2635         } else {
2636                 p->total_numa_faults = 0;
2637                 for (i = 0; i < NR_NUMA_HINT_FAULT_STATS * nr_node_ids; i++)
2638                         numa_faults[i] = 0;
2639         }
2640 }
2641 
2642 /*
2643  * Got a PROT_NONE fault for a page on @node.
2644  */
2645 void task_numa_fault(int last_cpupid, int mem_node, int pages, int flags)
     /*   */
2646 {
2647         struct task_struct *p = current;
2648         bool migrated = flags & TNF_MIGRATED;
2649         int cpu_node = task_node(current);
2650         int local = !!(flags & TNF_FAULT_LOCAL);
2651         struct numa_group *ng;
2652         int priv;
2653 
2654         if (!static_branch_likely(&sched_numa_balancing))
2655                 return;
2656 
2657         /* for example, ksmd faulting in a user's mm */
2658         if (!p->mm)
2659                 return;
2660 
2661         /* Allocate buffer to track faults on a per-node basis */
2662         if (unlikely(!p->numa_faults)) {
2663                 int size = sizeof(*p->numa_faults) *
2664                            NR_NUMA_HINT_FAULT_BUCKETS * nr_node_ids;
2665 
2666                 p->numa_faults = kzalloc(size, GFP_KERNEL|__GFP_NOWARN);
2667                 if (!p->numa_faults)
2668                         return;
2669 
2670                 p->total_numa_faults = 0;
2671                 memset(p->numa_faults_locality, 0, sizeof(p->numa_faults_locality));
2672         }
2673 
2674         /*
2675          * First accesses are treated as private, otherwise consider accesses
2676          * to be private if the accessing pid has not changed
2677          */
2678         if (unlikely(last_cpupid == (-1 & LAST_CPUPID_MASK))) {
2679                 priv = 1;
2680         } else {
2681                 priv = cpupid_match_pid(p, last_cpupid);
2682                 if (!priv && !(flags & TNF_NO_GROUP))
2683                         task_numa_group(p, last_cpupid, flags, &priv);
2684         }
2685 
2686         /*
2687          * If a workload spans multiple NUMA nodes, a shared fault that
2688          * occurs wholly within the set of nodes that the workload is
2689          * actively using should be counted as local. This allows the
2690          * scan rate to slow down when a workload has settled down.
2691          */
2692         ng = deref_curr_numa_group(p);
2693         if (!priv && !local && ng && ng->active_nodes > 1 &&
2694                                 numa_is_active_node(cpu_node, ng) &&
2695                                 numa_is_active_node(mem_node, ng))
2696                 local = 1;
2697 
2698         /*
2699          * Retry to migrate task to preferred node periodically, in case it
2700          * previously failed, or the scheduler moved us.
2701          */
2702         if (time_after(jiffies, p->numa_migrate_retry)) {
2703                 task_numa_placement(p);
2704                 numa_migrate_preferred(p);
2705         }
2706 
2707         if (migrated)
2708                 p->numa_pages_migrated += pages;
2709         if (flags & TNF_MIGRATE_FAIL)
2710                 p->numa_faults_locality[2] += pages;
2711 
2712         p->numa_faults[task_faults_idx(NUMA_MEMBUF, mem_node, priv)] += pages;
2713         p->numa_faults[task_faults_idx(NUMA_CPUBUF, cpu_node, priv)] += pages;
2714         p->numa_faults_locality[local] += pages;
2715 }
2716 
2717 static void reset_ptenuma_scan(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
2718 {
2719         /*
2720          * We only did a read acquisition of the mmap sem, so
2721          * p->mm->numa_scan_seq is written to without exclusive access
2722          * and the update is not guaranteed to be atomic. That's not
2723          * much of an issue though, since this is just used for
2724          * statistical sampling. Use READ_ONCE/WRITE_ONCE, which are not
2725          * expensive, to avoid any form of compiler optimizations:
2726          */
2727         WRITE_ONCE(p->mm->numa_scan_seq, READ_ONCE(p->mm->numa_scan_seq) + 1);
2728         p->mm->numa_scan_offset = 0;
2729 }
2730 
2731 /*
2732  * The expensive part of numa migration is done from task_work context.
2733  * Triggered from task_tick_numa().
2734  */
2735 static void task_numa_work(struct callback_head *work)
     /*   */
2736 {
2737         unsigned long migrate, next_scan, now = jiffies;
2738         struct task_struct *p = current;
2739         struct mm_struct *mm = p->mm;
2740         u64 runtime = p->se.sum_exec_runtime;
2741         struct vm_area_struct *vma;
2742         unsigned long start, end;
2743         unsigned long nr_pte_updates = 0;
2744         long pages, virtpages;
2745 
2746         SCHED_WARN_ON(p != container_of(work, struct task_struct, numa_work));
2747 
2748         work->next = work;
2749         /*
2750          * Who cares about NUMA placement when they're dying.
2751          *
2752          * NOTE: make sure not to dereference p->mm before this check,
2753          * exit_task_work() happens _after_ exit_mm() so we could be called
2754          * without p->mm even though we still had it when we enqueued this
2755          * work.
2756          */
2757         if (p->flags & PF_EXITING)
2758                 return;
2759 
2760         if (!mm->numa_next_scan) {
2761                 mm->numa_next_scan = now +
2762                         msecs_to_jiffies(sysctl_numa_balancing_scan_delay);
2763         }
2764 
2765         /*
2766          * Enforce maximal scan/migration frequency..
2767          */
2768         migrate = mm->numa_next_scan;
2769         if (time_before(now, migrate))
2770                 return;
2771 
2772         if (p->numa_scan_period == 0) {
2773                 p->numa_scan_period_max = task_scan_max(p);
2774                 p->numa_scan_period = task_scan_start(p);
2775         }
2776 
2777         next_scan = now + msecs_to_jiffies(p->numa_scan_period);
2778         if (cmpxchg(&mm->numa_next_scan, migrate, next_scan) != migrate)
2779                 return;
2780 
2781         /*
2782          * Delay this task enough that another task of this mm will likely win
2783          * the next time around.
2784          */
2785         p->node_stamp += 2 * TICK_NSEC;
2786 
2787         start = mm->numa_scan_offset;
2788         pages = sysctl_numa_balancing_scan_size;
2789         pages <<= 20 - PAGE_SHIFT; /* MB in pages */
2790         virtpages = pages * 8;     /* Scan up to this much virtual space */
2791         if (!pages)
2792                 return;
2793 
2794 
2795         if (!mmap_read_trylock(mm))
2796                 return;
2797         vma = find_vma(mm, start);
2798         if (!vma) {
2799                 reset_ptenuma_scan(p);
2800                 start = 0;
2801                 vma = mm->mmap;
2802         }
2803         for (; vma; vma = vma->vm_next) {
2804                 if (!vma_migratable(vma) || !vma_policy_mof(vma) ||
2805                         is_vm_hugetlb_page(vma) || (vma->vm_flags & VM_MIXEDMAP)) {
2806                         continue;
2807                 }
2808 
2809                 /*
2810                  * Shared library pages mapped by multiple processes are not
2811                  * migrated as it is expected they are cache replicated. Avoid
2812                  * hinting faults in read-only file-backed mappings or the vdso
2813                  * as migrating the pages will be of marginal benefit.
2814                  */
2815                 if (!vma->vm_mm ||
2816                     (vma->vm_file && (vma->vm_flags & (VM_READ|VM_WRITE)) == (VM_READ)))
2817                         continue;
2818 
2819                 /*
2820                  * Skip inaccessible VMAs to avoid any confusion between
2821                  * PROT_NONE and NUMA hinting ptes
2822                  */
2823                 if (!vma_is_accessible(vma))
2824                         continue;
2825 
2826                 do {
2827                         start = max(start, vma->vm_start);
2828                         end = ALIGN(start + (pages << PAGE_SHIFT), HPAGE_SIZE);
2829                         end = min(end, vma->vm_end);
2830                         nr_pte_updates = change_prot_numa(vma, start, end);
2831 
2832                         /*
2833                          * Try to scan sysctl_numa_balancing_size worth of
2834                          * hpages that have at least one present PTE that
2835                          * is not already pte-numa. If the VMA contains
2836                          * areas that are unused or already full of prot_numa
2837                          * PTEs, scan up to virtpages, to skip through those
2838                          * areas faster.
2839                          */
2840                         if (nr_pte_updates)
2841                                 pages -= (end - start) >> PAGE_SHIFT;
2842                         virtpages -= (end - start) >> PAGE_SHIFT;
2843 
2844                         start = end;
2845                         if (pages <= 0 || virtpages <= 0)
2846                                 goto out;
2847 
2848                         cond_resched();
2849                 } while (end != vma->vm_end);
2850         }
2851 
2852 out:
2853         /*
2854          * It is possible to reach the end of the VMA list but the last few
2855          * VMAs are not guaranteed to the vma_migratable. If they are not, we
2856          * would find the !migratable VMA on the next scan but not reset the
2857          * scanner to the start so check it now.
2858          */
2859         if (vma)
2860                 mm->numa_scan_offset = start;
2861         else
2862                 reset_ptenuma_scan(p);
2863         mmap_read_unlock(mm);
2864 
2865         /*
2866          * Make sure tasks use at least 32x as much time to run other code
2867          * than they used here, to limit NUMA PTE scanning overhead to 3% max.
2868          * Usually update_task_scan_period slows down scanning enough; on an
2869          * overloaded system we need to limit overhead on a per task basis.
2870          */
2871         if (unlikely(p->se.sum_exec_runtime != runtime)) {
2872                 u64 diff = p->se.sum_exec_runtime - runtime;
2873                 p->node_stamp += 32 * diff;
2874         }
2875 }
2876 
2877 void init_numa_balancing(unsigned long clone_flags, struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
2878 {
2879         int mm_users = 0;
2880         struct mm_struct *mm = p->mm;
2881 
2882         if (mm) {
2883                 mm_users = atomic_read(&mm->mm_users);
2884                 if (mm_users == 1) {
2885                         mm->numa_next_scan = jiffies + msecs_to_jiffies(sysctl_numa_balancing_scan_delay);
2886                         mm->numa_scan_seq = 0;
2887                 }
2888         }
2889         p->node_stamp                   = 0;
2890         p->numa_scan_seq                = mm ? mm->numa_scan_seq : 0;
2891         p->numa_scan_period             = sysctl_numa_balancing_scan_delay;
2892         /* Protect against double add, see task_tick_numa and task_numa_work */
2893         p->numa_work.next               = &p->numa_work;
2894         p->numa_faults                  = NULL;
2895         RCU_INIT_POINTER(p->numa_group, NULL);
2896         p->last_task_numa_placement     = 0;
2897         p->last_sum_exec_runtime        = 0;
2898 
2899         init_task_work(&p->numa_work, task_numa_work);
2900 
2901         /* New address space, reset the preferred nid */
2902         if (!(clone_flags & CLONE_VM)) {
2903                 p->numa_preferred_nid = NUMA_NO_NODE;
2904                 return;
2905         }
2906 
2907         /*
2908          * New thread, keep existing numa_preferred_nid which should be copied
2909          * already by arch_dup_task_struct but stagger when scans start.
2910          */
2911         if (mm) {
2912                 unsigned int delay;
2913 
2914                 delay = min_t(unsigned int, task_scan_max(current),
2915                         current->numa_scan_period * mm_users * NSEC_PER_MSEC);
2916                 delay += 2 * TICK_NSEC;
2917                 p->node_stamp = delay;
2918         }
2919 }
2920 
2921 /*
2922  * Drive the periodic memory faults..
2923  */
2924 static void task_tick_numa(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *curr)
     /*   */
2925 {
2926         struct callback_head *work = &curr->numa_work;
2927         u64 period, now;
2928 
2929         /*
2930          * We don't care about NUMA placement if we don't have memory.
2931          */
2932         if ((curr->flags & (PF_EXITING | PF_KTHREAD)) || work->next != work)
2933                 return;
2934 
2935         /*
2936          * Using runtime rather than walltime has the dual advantage that
2937          * we (mostly) drive the selection from busy threads and that the
2938          * task needs to have done some actual work before we bother with
2939          * NUMA placement.
2940          */
2941         now = curr->se.sum_exec_runtime;
2942         period = (u64)curr->numa_scan_period * NSEC_PER_MSEC;
2943 
2944         if (now > curr->node_stamp + period) {
2945                 if (!curr->node_stamp)
2946                         curr->numa_scan_period = task_scan_start(curr);
2947                 curr->node_stamp += period;
2948 
2949                 if (!time_before(jiffies, curr->mm->numa_next_scan))
2950                         task_work_add(curr, work, TWA_RESUME);
2951         }
2952 }
2953 
2954 static void update_scan_period(struct task_struct *p, int new_cpu)
     /*   */
2955 {
2956         int src_nid = cpu_to_node(task_cpu(p));
2957         int dst_nid = cpu_to_node(new_cpu);
2958 
2959         if (!static_branch_likely(&sched_numa_balancing))
2960                 return;
2961 
2962         if (!p->mm || !p->numa_faults || (p->flags & PF_EXITING))
2963                 return;
2964 
2965         if (src_nid == dst_nid)
2966                 return;
2967 
2968         /*
2969          * Allow resets if faults have been trapped before one scan
2970          * has completed. This is most likely due to a new task that
2971          * is pulled cross-node due to wakeups or load balancing.
2972          */
2973         if (p->numa_scan_seq) {
2974                 /*
2975                  * Avoid scan adjustments if moving to the preferred
2976                  * node or if the task was not previously running on
2977                  * the preferred node.
2978                  */
2979                 if (dst_nid == p->numa_preferred_nid ||
2980                     (p->numa_preferred_nid != NUMA_NO_NODE &&
2981                         src_nid != p->numa_preferred_nid))
2982                         return;
2983         }
2984 
2985         p->numa_scan_period = task_scan_start(p);
2986 }
2987 
2988 #else
2989 static void task_tick_numa(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *curr)
     /*   */
2990 {
2991 }
2992 
2993 static inline void account_numa_enqueue(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
2994 {
2995 }
2996 
2997 static inline void account_numa_dequeue(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
2998 {
2999 }
3000 
3001 static inline void update_scan_period(struct task_struct *p, int new_cpu)
     /*   */
3002 {
3003 }
3004 
3005 #endif /* CONFIG_NUMA_BALANCING */
3006 
3007 static void
3008 account_entity_enqueue(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3009 {
3010         update_load_add(&cfs_rq->load, se->load.weight);
3011 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3012         if (entity_is_task(se)) {
3013                 struct rq *rq = rq_of(cfs_rq);
3014 
3015                 account_numa_enqueue(rq, task_of(se));
3016                 list_add(&se->group_node, &rq->cfs_tasks);
3017         }
3018 #endif
3019         cfs_rq->nr_running++;
3020 }
3021 
3022 static void
3023 account_entity_dequeue(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3024 {
3025         update_load_sub(&cfs_rq->load, se->load.weight);
3026 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3027         if (entity_is_task(se)) {
3028                 account_numa_dequeue(rq_of(cfs_rq), task_of(se));
3029                 list_del_init(&se->group_node);
3030         }
3031 #endif
3032         cfs_rq->nr_running--;
3033 }
3034 
3035 /*
3036  * Signed add and clamp on underflow.
3037  *
3038  * Explicitly do a load-store to ensure the intermediate value never hits
3039  * memory. This allows lockless observations without ever seeing the negative
3040  * values.
3041  */
3042 #define add_positive(_ptr, _val) do {                           \
3043         typeof(_ptr) ptr = (_ptr);                              \
3044         typeof(_val) val = (_val);                              \
3045         typeof(*ptr) res, var = READ_ONCE(*ptr);                \
3046                                                                 \
3047         res = var + val;                                        \
3048                                                                 \
3049         if (val < 0 && res > var)                               \
3050                 res = 0;                                        \
3051                                                                 \
3052         WRITE_ONCE(*ptr, res);                                  \
3053 } while (0)
3054 
3055 /*
3056  * Unsigned subtract and clamp on underflow.
3057  *
3058  * Explicitly do a load-store to ensure the intermediate value never hits
3059  * memory. This allows lockless observations without ever seeing the negative
3060  * values.
3061  */
3062 #define sub_positive(_ptr, _val) do {                           \
3063         typeof(_ptr) ptr = (_ptr);                              \
3064         typeof(*ptr) val = (_val);                              \
3065         typeof(*ptr) res, var = READ_ONCE(*ptr);                \
3066         res = var - val;                                        \
3067         if (res > var)                                          \
3068                 res = 0;                                        \
3069         WRITE_ONCE(*ptr, res);                                  \
3070 } while (0)
3071 
3072 /*
3073  * Remove and clamp on negative, from a local variable.
3074  *
3075  * A variant of sub_positive(), which does not use explicit load-store
3076  * and is thus optimized for local variable updates.
3077  */
3078 #define lsub_positive(_ptr, _val) do {                          \
3079         typeof(_ptr) ptr = (_ptr);                              \
3080         *ptr -= min_t(typeof(*ptr), *ptr, _val);                \
3081 } while (0)
3082 
3083 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3084 static inline void
3085 enqueue_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3086 {
3087         cfs_rq->avg.load_avg += se->avg.load_avg;
3088         cfs_rq->avg.load_sum += se_weight(se) * se->avg.load_sum;
3089 }
3090 
3091 static inline void
3092 dequeue_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3093 {
3094         sub_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.load_avg, se->avg.load_avg);
3095         sub_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.load_sum, se_weight(se) * se->avg.load_sum);
3096 }
3097 #else
3098 static inline void
3099 enqueue_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se) { }
     /*   */
3100 static inline void
3101 dequeue_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se) { }
     /*   */
3102 #endif
3103 
3104 static void reweight_entity(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se,
     /*   */
3105                             unsigned long weight)
3106 {
3107         if (se->on_rq) {
3108                 /* commit outstanding execution time */
3109                 if (cfs_rq->curr == se)
3110                         update_curr(cfs_rq);
3111                 update_load_sub(&cfs_rq->load, se->load.weight);
3112         }
3113         dequeue_load_avg(cfs_rq, se);
3114 
3115         update_load_set(&se->load, weight);
3116 
3117 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3118         do {
3119                 u32 divider = get_pelt_divider(&se->avg);
3120 
3121                 se->avg.load_avg = div_u64(se_weight(se) * se->avg.load_sum, divider);
3122         } while (0);
3123 #endif
3124 
3125         enqueue_load_avg(cfs_rq, se);
3126         if (se->on_rq)
3127                 update_load_add(&cfs_rq->load, se->load.weight);
3128 
3129 }
3130 
3131 void reweight_task(struct task_struct *p, int prio)
     /*   */
3132 {
3133         struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
3134         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
3135         struct load_weight *load = &se->load;
3136         unsigned long weight = scale_load(sched_prio_to_weight[prio]);
3137 
3138         reweight_entity(cfs_rq, se, weight);
3139         load->inv_weight = sched_prio_to_wmult[prio];
3140 }
3141 
3142 #ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
3143 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3144 /*
3145  * All this does is approximate the hierarchical proportion which includes that
3146  * global sum we all love to hate.
3147  *
3148  * That is, the weight of a group entity, is the proportional share of the
3149  * group weight based on the group runqueue weights. That is:
3150  *
3151  *                     tg->weight * grq->load.weight
3152  *   ge->load.weight = -----------------------------               (1)
3153  *                        \Sum grq->load.weight
3154  *
3155  * Now, because computing that sum is prohibitively expensive to compute (been
3156  * there, done that) we approximate it with this average stuff. The average
3157  * moves slower and therefore the approximation is cheaper and more stable.
3158  *
3159  * So instead of the above, we substitute:
3160  *
3161  *   grq->load.weight -> grq->avg.load_avg                         (2)
3162  *
3163  * which yields the following:
3164  *
3165  *                     tg->weight * grq->avg.load_avg
3166  *   ge->load.weight = ------------------------------              (3)
3167  *                              tg->load_avg
3168  *
3169  * Where: tg->load_avg ~= \Sum grq->avg.load_avg
3170  *
3171  * That is shares_avg, and it is right (given the approximation (2)).
3172  *
3173  * The problem with it is that because the average is slow -- it was designed
3174  * to be exactly that of course -- this leads to transients in boundary
3175  * conditions. In specific, the case where the group was idle and we start the
3176  * one task. It takes time for our CPU's grq->avg.load_avg to build up,
3177  * yielding bad latency etc..
3178  *
3179  * Now, in that special case (1) reduces to:
3180  *
3181  *                     tg->weight * grq->load.weight
3182  *   ge->load.weight = ----------------------------- = tg->weight   (4)
3183  *                          grp->load.weight
3184  *
3185  * That is, the sum collapses because all other CPUs are idle; the UP scenario.
3186  *
3187  * So what we do is modify our approximation (3) to approach (4) in the (near)
3188  * UP case, like:
3189  *
3190  *   ge->load.weight =
3191  *
3192  *              tg->weight * grq->load.weight
3193  *     ---------------------------------------------------         (5)
3194  *     tg->load_avg - grq->avg.load_avg + grq->load.weight
3195  *
3196  * But because grq->load.weight can drop to 0, resulting in a divide by zero,
3197  * we need to use grq->avg.load_avg as its lower bound, which then gives:
3198  *
3199  *
3200  *                     tg->weight * grq->load.weight
3201  *   ge->load.weight = -----------------------------               (6)
3202  *                              tg_load_avg'
3203  *
3204  * Where:
3205  *
3206  *   tg_load_avg' = tg->load_avg - grq->avg.load_avg +
3207  *                  max(grq->load.weight, grq->avg.load_avg)
3208  *
3209  * And that is shares_weight and is icky. In the (near) UP case it approaches
3210  * (4) while in the normal case it approaches (3). It consistently
3211  * overestimates the ge->load.weight and therefore:
3212  *
3213  *   \Sum ge->load.weight >= tg->weight
3214  *
3215  * hence icky!
3216  */
3217 static long calc_group_shares(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
3218 {
3219         long tg_weight, tg_shares, load, shares;
3220         struct task_group *tg = cfs_rq->tg;
3221 
3222         tg_shares = READ_ONCE(tg->shares);
3223 
3224         load = max(scale_load_down(cfs_rq->load.weight), cfs_rq->avg.load_avg);
3225 
3226         tg_weight = atomic_long_read(&tg->load_avg);
3227 
3228         /* Ensure tg_weight >= load */
3229         tg_weight -= cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib;
3230         tg_weight += load;
3231 
3232         shares = (tg_shares * load);
3233         if (tg_weight)
3234                 shares /= tg_weight;
3235 
3236         /*
3237          * MIN_SHARES has to be unscaled here to support per-CPU partitioning
3238          * of a group with small tg->shares value. It is a floor value which is
3239          * assigned as a minimum load.weight to the sched_entity representing
3240          * the group on a CPU.
3241          *
3242          * E.g. on 64-bit for a group with tg->shares of scale_load(15)=15*1024
3243          * on an 8-core system with 8 tasks each runnable on one CPU shares has
3244          * to be 15*1024*1/8=1920 instead of scale_load(MIN_SHARES)=2*1024. In
3245          * case no task is runnable on a CPU MIN_SHARES=2 should be returned
3246          * instead of 0.
3247          */
3248         return clamp_t(long, shares, MIN_SHARES, tg_shares);
3249 }
3250 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
3251 
3252 static inline int throttled_hierarchy(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq);
3253 
3254 /*
3255  * Recomputes the group entity based on the current state of its group
3256  * runqueue.
3257  */
3258 static void update_cfs_group(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3259 {
3260         struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
3261         long shares;
3262 
3263         if (!gcfs_rq)
3264                 return;
3265 
3266         if (throttled_hierarchy(gcfs_rq))
3267                 return;
3268 
3269 #ifndef CONFIG_SMP
3270         shares = READ_ONCE(gcfs_rq->tg->shares);
3271 
3272         if (likely(se->load.weight == shares))
3273                 return;
3274 #else
3275         shares   = calc_group_shares(gcfs_rq);
3276 #endif
3277 
3278         reweight_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se, shares);
3279 }
3280 
3281 #else /* CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED */
3282 static inline void update_cfs_group(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3283 {
3284 }
3285 #endif /* CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED */
3286 
3287 static inline void cfs_rq_util_change(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, int flags)
     /*   */
3288 {
3289         struct rq *rq = rq_of(cfs_rq);
3290 
3291         if (&rq->cfs == cfs_rq) {
3292                 /*
3293                  * There are a few boundary cases this might miss but it should
3294                  * get called often enough that that should (hopefully) not be
3295                  * a real problem.
3296                  *
3297                  * It will not get called when we go idle, because the idle
3298                  * thread is a different class (!fair), nor will the utilization
3299                  * number include things like RT tasks.
3300                  *
3301                  * As is, the util number is not freq-invariant (we'd have to
3302                  * implement arch_scale_freq_capacity() for that).
3303                  *
3304                  * See cpu_util().
3305                  */
3306                 cpufreq_update_util(rq, flags);
3307         }
3308 }
3309 
3310 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
3311 #ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
3312 /**
3313  * update_tg_load_avg - update the tg's load avg
3314  * @cfs_rq: the cfs_rq whose avg changed
3315  *
3316  * This function 'ensures': tg->load_avg := \Sum tg->cfs_rq[]->avg.load.
3317  * However, because tg->load_avg is a global value there are performance
3318  * considerations.
3319  *
3320  * In order to avoid having to look at the other cfs_rq's, we use a
3321  * differential update where we store the last value we propagated. This in
3322  * turn allows skipping updates if the differential is 'small'.
3323  *
3324  * Updating tg's load_avg is necessary before update_cfs_share().
3325  */
3326 static inline void update_tg_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
3327 {
3328         long delta = cfs_rq->avg.load_avg - cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib;
3329 
3330         /*
3331          * No need to update load_avg for root_task_group as it is not used.
3332          */
3333         if (cfs_rq->tg == &root_task_group)
3334                 return;
3335 
3336         if (abs(delta) > cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib / 64) {
3337                 atomic_long_add(delta, &cfs_rq->tg->load_avg);
3338                 cfs_rq->tg_load_avg_contrib = cfs_rq->avg.load_avg;
3339         }
3340 }
3341 
3342 /*
3343  * Called within set_task_rq() right before setting a task's CPU. The
3344  * caller only guarantees p->pi_lock is held; no other assumptions,
3345  * including the state of rq->lock, should be made.
3346  */
3347 void set_task_rq_fair(struct sched_entity *se,
     /*   */
3348                       struct cfs_rq *prev, struct cfs_rq *next)
3349 {
3350         u64 p_last_update_time;
3351         u64 n_last_update_time;
3352 
3353         if (!sched_feat(ATTACH_AGE_LOAD))
3354                 return;
3355 
3356         /*
3357          * We are supposed to update the task to "current" time, then its up to
3358          * date and ready to go to new CPU/cfs_rq. But we have difficulty in
3359          * getting what current time is, so simply throw away the out-of-date
3360          * time. This will result in the wakee task is less decayed, but giving
3361          * the wakee more load sounds not bad.
3362          */
3363         if (!(se->avg.last_update_time && prev))
3364                 return;
3365 
3366 #ifndef CONFIG_64BIT
3367         {
3368                 u64 p_last_update_time_copy;
3369                 u64 n_last_update_time_copy;
3370 
3371                 do {
3372                         p_last_update_time_copy = prev->load_last_update_time_copy;
3373                         n_last_update_time_copy = next->load_last_update_time_copy;
3374 
3375                         smp_rmb();
3376 
3377                         p_last_update_time = prev->avg.last_update_time;
3378                         n_last_update_time = next->avg.last_update_time;
3379 
3380                 } while (p_last_update_time != p_last_update_time_copy ||
3381                          n_last_update_time != n_last_update_time_copy);
3382         }
3383 #else
3384         p_last_update_time = prev->avg.last_update_time;
3385         n_last_update_time = next->avg.last_update_time;
3386 #endif
3387         __update_load_avg_blocked_se(p_last_update_time, se);
3388         se->avg.last_update_time = n_last_update_time;
3389 }
3390 
3391 
3392 /*
3393  * When on migration a sched_entity joins/leaves the PELT hierarchy, we need to
3394  * propagate its contribution. The key to this propagation is the invariant
3395  * that for each group:
3396  *
3397  *   ge->avg == grq->avg                                                (1)
3398  *
3399  * _IFF_ we look at the pure running and runnable sums. Because they
3400  * represent the very same entity, just at different points in the hierarchy.
3401  *
3402  * Per the above update_tg_cfs_util() and update_tg_cfs_runnable() are trivial
3403  * and simply copies the running/runnable sum over (but still wrong, because
3404  * the group entity and group rq do not have their PELT windows aligned).
3405  *
3406  * However, update_tg_cfs_load() is more complex. So we have:
3407  *
3408  *   ge->avg.load_avg = ge->load.weight * ge->avg.runnable_avg          (2)
3409  *
3410  * And since, like util, the runnable part should be directly transferable,
3411  * the following would _appear_ to be the straight forward approach:
3412  *
3413  *   grq->avg.load_avg = grq->load.weight * grq->avg.runnable_avg       (3)
3414  *
3415  * And per (1) we have:
3416  *
3417  *   ge->avg.runnable_avg == grq->avg.runnable_avg
3418  *
3419  * Which gives:
3420  *
3421  *                      ge->load.weight * grq->avg.load_avg
3422  *   ge->avg.load_avg = -----------------------------------             (4)
3423  *                               grq->load.weight
3424  *
3425  * Except that is wrong!
3426  *
3427  * Because while for entities historical weight is not important and we
3428  * really only care about our future and therefore can consider a pure
3429  * runnable sum, runqueues can NOT do this.
3430  *
3431  * We specifically want runqueues to have a load_avg that includes
3432  * historical weights. Those represent the blocked load, the load we expect
3433  * to (shortly) return to us. This only works by keeping the weights as
3434  * integral part of the sum. We therefore cannot decompose as per (3).
3435  *
3436  * Another reason this doesn't work is that runnable isn't a 0-sum entity.
3437  * Imagine a rq with 2 tasks that each are runnable 2/3 of the time. Then the
3438  * rq itself is runnable anywhere between 2/3 and 1 depending on how the
3439  * runnable section of these tasks overlap (or not). If they were to perfectly
3440  * align the rq as a whole would be runnable 2/3 of the time. If however we
3441  * always have at least 1 runnable task, the rq as a whole is always runnable.
3442  *
3443  * So we'll have to approximate.. :/
3444  *
3445  * Given the constraint:
3446  *
3447  *   ge->avg.running_sum <= ge->avg.runnable_sum <= LOAD_AVG_MAX
3448  *
3449  * We can construct a rule that adds runnable to a rq by assuming minimal
3450  * overlap.
3451  *
3452  * On removal, we'll assume each task is equally runnable; which yields:
3453  *
3454  *   grq->avg.runnable_sum = grq->avg.load_sum / grq->load.weight
3455  *
3456  * XXX: only do this for the part of runnable > running ?
3457  *
3458  */
3459 
3460 static inline void
3461 update_tg_cfs_util(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se, struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq)
     /*   */
3462 {
3463         long delta = gcfs_rq->avg.util_avg - se->avg.util_avg;
3464         u32 divider;
3465 
3466         /* Nothing to update */
3467         if (!delta)
3468                 return;
3469 
3470         /*
3471          * cfs_rq->avg.period_contrib can be used for both cfs_rq and se.
3472          * See ___update_load_avg() for details.
3473          */
3474         divider = get_pelt_divider(&cfs_rq->avg);
3475 
3476         /* Set new sched_entity's utilization */
3477         se->avg.util_avg = gcfs_rq->avg.util_avg;
3478         se->avg.util_sum = se->avg.util_avg * divider;
3479 
3480         /* Update parent cfs_rq utilization */
3481         add_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.util_avg, delta);
3482         cfs_rq->avg.util_sum = cfs_rq->avg.util_avg * divider;
3483 }
3484 
3485 static inline void
3486 update_tg_cfs_runnable(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se, struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq)
     /*   */
3487 {
3488         long delta = gcfs_rq->avg.runnable_avg - se->avg.runnable_avg;
3489         u32 divider;
3490 
3491         /* Nothing to update */
3492         if (!delta)
3493                 return;
3494 
3495         /*
3496          * cfs_rq->avg.period_contrib can be used for both cfs_rq and se.
3497          * See ___update_load_avg() for details.
3498          */
3499         divider = get_pelt_divider(&cfs_rq->avg);
3500 
3501         /* Set new sched_entity's runnable */
3502         se->avg.runnable_avg = gcfs_rq->avg.runnable_avg;
3503         se->avg.runnable_sum = se->avg.runnable_avg * divider;
3504 
3505         /* Update parent cfs_rq runnable */
3506         add_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.runnable_avg, delta);
3507         cfs_rq->avg.runnable_sum = cfs_rq->avg.runnable_avg * divider;
3508 }
3509 
3510 static inline void
3511 update_tg_cfs_load(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se, struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq)
     /*   */
3512 {
3513         long delta_avg, running_sum, runnable_sum = gcfs_rq->prop_runnable_sum;
3514         unsigned long load_avg;
3515         u64 load_sum = 0;
3516         s64 delta_sum;
3517         u32 divider;
3518 
3519         if (!runnable_sum)
3520                 return;
3521 
3522         gcfs_rq->prop_runnable_sum = 0;
3523 
3524         /*
3525          * cfs_rq->avg.period_contrib can be used for both cfs_rq and se.
3526          * See ___update_load_avg() for details.
3527          */
3528         divider = get_pelt_divider(&cfs_rq->avg);
3529 
3530         if (runnable_sum >= 0) {
3531                 /*
3532                  * Add runnable; clip at LOAD_AVG_MAX. Reflects that until
3533                  * the CPU is saturated running == runnable.
3534                  */
3535                 runnable_sum += se->avg.load_sum;
3536                 runnable_sum = min_t(long, runnable_sum, divider);
3537         } else {
3538                 /*
3539                  * Estimate the new unweighted runnable_sum of the gcfs_rq by
3540                  * assuming all tasks are equally runnable.
3541                  */
3542                 if (scale_load_down(gcfs_rq->load.weight)) {
3543                         load_sum = div_s64(gcfs_rq->avg.load_sum,
3544                                 scale_load_down(gcfs_rq->load.weight));
3545                 }
3546 
3547                 /* But make sure to not inflate se's runnable */
3548                 runnable_sum = min(se->avg.load_sum, load_sum);
3549         }
3550 
3551         /*
3552          * runnable_sum can't be lower than running_sum
3553          * Rescale running sum to be in the same range as runnable sum
3554          * running_sum is in [0 : LOAD_AVG_MAX <<  SCHED_CAPACITY_SHIFT]
3555          * runnable_sum is in [0 : LOAD_AVG_MAX]
3556          */
3557         running_sum = se->avg.util_sum >> SCHED_CAPACITY_SHIFT;
3558         runnable_sum = max(runnable_sum, running_sum);
3559 
3560         load_sum = (s64)se_weight(se) * runnable_sum;
3561         load_avg = div_s64(load_sum, divider);
3562 
3563         delta_sum = load_sum - (s64)se_weight(se) * se->avg.load_sum;
3564         delta_avg = load_avg - se->avg.load_avg;
3565 
3566         se->avg.load_sum = runnable_sum;
3567         se->avg.load_avg = load_avg;
3568         add_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.load_avg, delta_avg);
3569         add_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.load_sum, delta_sum);
3570 }
3571 
3572 static inline void add_tg_cfs_propagate(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, long runnable_sum)
     /*   */
3573 {
3574         cfs_rq->propagate = 1;
3575         cfs_rq->prop_runnable_sum += runnable_sum;
3576 }
3577 
3578 /* Update task and its cfs_rq load average */
3579 static inline int propagate_entity_load_avg(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3580 {
3581         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, *gcfs_rq;
3582 
3583         if (entity_is_task(se))
3584                 return 0;
3585 
3586         gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
3587         if (!gcfs_rq->propagate)
3588                 return 0;
3589 
3590         gcfs_rq->propagate = 0;
3591 
3592         cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
3593 
3594         add_tg_cfs_propagate(cfs_rq, gcfs_rq->prop_runnable_sum);
3595 
3596         update_tg_cfs_util(cfs_rq, se, gcfs_rq);
3597         update_tg_cfs_runnable(cfs_rq, se, gcfs_rq);
3598         update_tg_cfs_load(cfs_rq, se, gcfs_rq);
3599 
3600         trace_pelt_cfs_tp(cfs_rq);
3601         trace_pelt_se_tp(se);
3602 
3603         return 1;
3604 }
3605 
3606 /*
3607  * Check if we need to update the load and the utilization of a blocked
3608  * group_entity:
3609  */
3610 static inline bool skip_blocked_update(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3611 {
3612         struct cfs_rq *gcfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
3613 
3614         /*
3615          * If sched_entity still have not zero load or utilization, we have to
3616          * decay it:
3617          */
3618         if (se->avg.load_avg || se->avg.util_avg)
3619                 return false;
3620 
3621         /*
3622          * If there is a pending propagation, we have to update the load and
3623          * the utilization of the sched_entity:
3624          */
3625         if (gcfs_rq->propagate)
3626                 return false;
3627 
3628         /*
3629          * Otherwise, the load and the utilization of the sched_entity is
3630          * already zero and there is no pending propagation, so it will be a
3631          * waste of time to try to decay it:
3632          */
3633         return true;
3634 }
3635 
3636 #else /* CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED */
3637 
3638 static inline void update_tg_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq) {}
     /*   */
3639 
3640 static inline int propagate_entity_load_avg(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3641 {
3642         return 0;
3643 }
3644 
3645 static inline void add_tg_cfs_propagate(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, long runnable_sum) {}
     /*   */
3646 
3647 #endif /* CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED */
3648 
3649 /**
3650  * update_cfs_rq_load_avg - update the cfs_rq's load/util averages
3651  * @now: current time, as per cfs_rq_clock_pelt()
3652  * @cfs_rq: cfs_rq to update
3653  *
3654  * The cfs_rq avg is the direct sum of all its entities (blocked and runnable)
3655  * avg. The immediate corollary is that all (fair) tasks must be attached, see
3656  * post_init_entity_util_avg().
3657  *
3658  * cfs_rq->avg is used for task_h_load() and update_cfs_share() for example.
3659  *
3660  * Returns true if the load decayed or we removed load.
3661  *
3662  * Since both these conditions indicate a changed cfs_rq->avg.load we should
3663  * call update_tg_load_avg() when this function returns true.
3664  */
3665 static inline int
3666 update_cfs_rq_load_avg(u64 now, struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
3667 {
3668         unsigned long removed_load = 0, removed_util = 0, removed_runnable = 0;
3669         struct sched_avg *sa = &cfs_rq->avg;
3670         int decayed = 0;
3671 
3672         if (cfs_rq->removed.nr) {
3673                 unsigned long r;
3674                 u32 divider = get_pelt_divider(&cfs_rq->avg);
3675 
3676                 raw_spin_lock(&cfs_rq->removed.lock);
3677                 swap(cfs_rq->removed.util_avg, removed_util);
3678                 swap(cfs_rq->removed.load_avg, removed_load);
3679                 swap(cfs_rq->removed.runnable_avg, removed_runnable);
3680                 cfs_rq->removed.nr = 0;
3681                 raw_spin_unlock(&cfs_rq->removed.lock);
3682 
3683                 r = removed_load;
3684                 sub_positive(&sa->load_avg, r);
3685                 sub_positive(&sa->load_sum, r * divider);
3686 
3687                 r = removed_util;
3688                 sub_positive(&sa->util_avg, r);
3689                 sub_positive(&sa->util_sum, r * divider);
3690 
3691                 r = removed_runnable;
3692                 sub_positive(&sa->runnable_avg, r);
3693                 sub_positive(&sa->runnable_sum, r * divider);
3694 
3695                 /*
3696                  * removed_runnable is the unweighted version of removed_load so we
3697                  * can use it to estimate removed_load_sum.
3698                  */
3699                 add_tg_cfs_propagate(cfs_rq,
3700                         -(long)(removed_runnable * divider) >> SCHED_CAPACITY_SHIFT);
3701 
3702                 decayed = 1;
3703         }
3704 
3705         decayed |= __update_load_avg_cfs_rq(now, cfs_rq);
3706 
3707 #ifndef CONFIG_64BIT
3708         smp_wmb();
3709         cfs_rq->load_last_update_time_copy = sa->last_update_time;
3710 #endif
3711 
3712         return decayed;
3713 }
3714 
3715 /**
3716  * attach_entity_load_avg - attach this entity to its cfs_rq load avg
3717  * @cfs_rq: cfs_rq to attach to
3718  * @se: sched_entity to attach
3719  *
3720  * Must call update_cfs_rq_load_avg() before this, since we rely on
3721  * cfs_rq->avg.last_update_time being current.
3722  */
3723 static void attach_entity_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3724 {
3725         /*
3726          * cfs_rq->avg.period_contrib can be used for both cfs_rq and se.
3727          * See ___update_load_avg() for details.
3728          */
3729         u32 divider = get_pelt_divider(&cfs_rq->avg);
3730 
3731         /*
3732          * When we attach the @se to the @cfs_rq, we must align the decay
3733          * window because without that, really weird and wonderful things can
3734          * happen.
3735          *
3736          * XXX illustrate
3737          */
3738         se->avg.last_update_time = cfs_rq->avg.last_update_time;
3739         se->avg.period_contrib = cfs_rq->avg.period_contrib;
3740 
3741         /*
3742          * Hell(o) Nasty stuff.. we need to recompute _sum based on the new
3743          * period_contrib. This isn't strictly correct, but since we're
3744          * entirely outside of the PELT hierarchy, nobody cares if we truncate
3745          * _sum a little.
3746          */
3747         se->avg.util_sum = se->avg.util_avg * divider;
3748 
3749         se->avg.runnable_sum = se->avg.runnable_avg * divider;
3750 
3751         se->avg.load_sum = divider;
3752         if (se_weight(se)) {
3753                 se->avg.load_sum =
3754                         div_u64(se->avg.load_avg * se->avg.load_sum, se_weight(se));
3755         }
3756 
3757         enqueue_load_avg(cfs_rq, se);
3758         cfs_rq->avg.util_avg += se->avg.util_avg;
3759         cfs_rq->avg.util_sum += se->avg.util_sum;
3760         cfs_rq->avg.runnable_avg += se->avg.runnable_avg;
3761         cfs_rq->avg.runnable_sum += se->avg.runnable_sum;
3762 
3763         add_tg_cfs_propagate(cfs_rq, se->avg.load_sum);
3764 
3765         cfs_rq_util_change(cfs_rq, 0);
3766 
3767         trace_pelt_cfs_tp(cfs_rq);
3768 }
3769 
3770 /**
3771  * detach_entity_load_avg - detach this entity from its cfs_rq load avg
3772  * @cfs_rq: cfs_rq to detach from
3773  * @se: sched_entity to detach
3774  *
3775  * Must call update_cfs_rq_load_avg() before this, since we rely on
3776  * cfs_rq->avg.last_update_time being current.
3777  */
3778 static void detach_entity_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3779 {
3780         dequeue_load_avg(cfs_rq, se);
3781         sub_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.util_avg, se->avg.util_avg);
3782         sub_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.util_sum, se->avg.util_sum);
3783         sub_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.runnable_avg, se->avg.runnable_avg);
3784         sub_positive(&cfs_rq->avg.runnable_sum, se->avg.runnable_sum);
3785 
3786         add_tg_cfs_propagate(cfs_rq, -se->avg.load_sum);
3787 
3788         cfs_rq_util_change(cfs_rq, 0);
3789 
3790         trace_pelt_cfs_tp(cfs_rq);
3791 }
3792 
3793 /*
3794  * Optional action to be done while updating the load average
3795  */
3796 #define UPDATE_TG       0x1
3797 #define SKIP_AGE_LOAD   0x2
3798 #define DO_ATTACH       0x4
3799 
3800 /* Update task and its cfs_rq load average */
3801 static inline void update_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, struct sched_entity *se, int flags)
     /*   */
3802 {
3803         u64 now = cfs_rq_clock_pelt(cfs_rq);
3804         int decayed;
3805 
3806         trace_android_vh_prepare_update_load_avg_se(se, flags);
3807         /*
3808          * Track task load average for carrying it to new CPU after migrated, and
3809          * track group sched_entity load average for task_h_load calc in migration
3810          */
3811         if (se->avg.last_update_time && !(flags & SKIP_AGE_LOAD))
3812                 __update_load_avg_se(now, cfs_rq, se);
3813 
3814         trace_android_vh_finish_update_load_avg_se(se, flags);
3815 
3816         decayed  = update_cfs_rq_load_avg(now, cfs_rq);
3817         decayed |= propagate_entity_load_avg(se);
3818 
3819         if (!se->avg.last_update_time && (flags & DO_ATTACH)) {
3820 
3821                 /*
3822                  * DO_ATTACH means we're here from enqueue_entity().
3823                  * !last_update_time means we've passed through
3824                  * migrate_task_rq_fair() indicating we migrated.
3825                  *
3826                  * IOW we're enqueueing a task on a new CPU.
3827                  */
3828                 attach_entity_load_avg(cfs_rq, se);
3829                 update_tg_load_avg(cfs_rq);
3830 
3831         } else if (decayed) {
3832                 cfs_rq_util_change(cfs_rq, 0);
3833 
3834                 if (flags & UPDATE_TG)
3835                         update_tg_load_avg(cfs_rq);
3836         }
3837 }
3838 
3839 #ifndef CONFIG_64BIT
3840 static inline u64 cfs_rq_last_update_time(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
3841 {
3842         u64 last_update_time_copy;
3843         u64 last_update_time;
3844 
3845         do {
3846                 last_update_time_copy = cfs_rq->load_last_update_time_copy;
3847                 smp_rmb();
3848                 last_update_time = cfs_rq->avg.last_update_time;
3849         } while (last_update_time != last_update_time_copy);
3850 
3851         return last_update_time;
3852 }
3853 #else
3854 static inline u64 cfs_rq_last_update_time(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
3855 {
3856         return cfs_rq->avg.last_update_time;
3857 }
3858 #endif
3859 
3860 /*
3861  * Synchronize entity load avg of dequeued entity without locking
3862  * the previous rq.
3863  */
3864 static void sync_entity_load_avg(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3865 {
3866         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
3867         u64 last_update_time;
3868 
3869         last_update_time = cfs_rq_last_update_time(cfs_rq);
3870         __update_load_avg_blocked_se(last_update_time, se);
3871 }
3872 
3873 /*
3874  * Task first catches up with cfs_rq, and then subtract
3875  * itself from the cfs_rq (task must be off the queue now).
3876  */
3877 static void remove_entity_load_avg(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
3878 {
3879         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
3880         unsigned long flags;
3881 
3882         /*
3883          * tasks cannot exit without having gone through wake_up_new_task() ->
3884          * post_init_entity_util_avg() which will have added things to the
3885          * cfs_rq, so we can remove unconditionally.
3886          */
3887 
3888         sync_entity_load_avg(se);
3889 
3890         raw_spin_lock_irqsave(&cfs_rq->removed.lock, flags);
3891         ++cfs_rq->removed.nr;
3892         cfs_rq->removed.util_avg        += se->avg.util_avg;
3893         cfs_rq->removed.load_avg        += se->avg.load_avg;
3894         cfs_rq->removed.runnable_avg    += se->avg.runnable_avg;
3895         raw_spin_unlock_irqrestore(&cfs_rq->removed.lock, flags);
3896 }
3897 
3898 static inline unsigned long cfs_rq_runnable_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
3899 {
3900         return cfs_rq->avg.runnable_avg;
3901 }
3902 
3903 static inline unsigned long cfs_rq_load_avg(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
3904 {
3905         return cfs_rq->avg.load_avg;
3906 }
3907 
3908 static int newidle_balance(struct rq *this_rq, struct rq_flags *rf);
3909 
3910 static inline unsigned long task_util(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
3911 {
3912         return READ_ONCE(p->se.avg.util_avg);
3913 }
3914 
3915 static inline unsigned long _task_util_est(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
3916 {
3917         struct util_est ue = READ_ONCE(p->se.avg.util_est);
3918 
3919         return (max(ue.ewma, ue.enqueued) | UTIL_AVG_UNCHANGED);
3920 }
3921 
3922 static inline unsigned long task_util_est(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
3923 {
3924         return max(task_util(p), _task_util_est(p));
3925 }
3926 
3927 #ifdef CONFIG_UCLAMP_TASK
3928 static inline unsigned long uclamp_task_util(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
3929 {
3930         return clamp(task_util_est(p),
3931                      uclamp_eff_value(p, UCLAMP_MIN),
3932                      uclamp_eff_value(p, UCLAMP_MAX));
3933 }
3934 #else
3935 static inline unsigned long uclamp_task_util(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
3936 {
3937         return task_util_est(p);
3938 }
3939 #endif
3940 
3941 static inline void util_est_enqueue(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq,
     /*   */
3942                                     struct task_struct *p)
3943 {
3944         unsigned int enqueued;
3945 
3946         if (!sched_feat(UTIL_EST))
3947                 return;
3948 
3949         /* Update root cfs_rq's estimated utilization */
3950         enqueued  = cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued;
3951         enqueued += _task_util_est(p);
3952         WRITE_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued, enqueued);
3953 
3954         trace_sched_util_est_cfs_tp(cfs_rq);
3955 }
3956 
3957 static inline void util_est_dequeue(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq,
     /*   */
3958                                     struct task_struct *p)
3959 {
3960         unsigned int enqueued;
3961 
3962         if (!sched_feat(UTIL_EST))
3963                 return;
3964 
3965         /* Update root cfs_rq's estimated utilization */
3966         enqueued  = cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued;
3967         enqueued -= min_t(unsigned int, enqueued, _task_util_est(p));
3968         WRITE_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued, enqueued);
3969 
3970         trace_sched_util_est_cfs_tp(cfs_rq);
3971 }
3972 
3973 #define UTIL_EST_MARGIN (SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE / 100)
3974 
3975 /*
3976  * Check if a (signed) value is within a specified (unsigned) margin,
3977  * based on the observation that:
3978  *
3979  *     abs(x) < y := (unsigned)(x + y - 1) < (2 * y - 1)
3980  *
3981  * NOTE: this only works when value + maring < INT_MAX.
3982  */
3983 static inline bool within_margin(int value, int margin)
     /*   */
3984 {
3985         return ((unsigned int)(value + margin - 1) < (2 * margin - 1));
3986 }
3987 
3988 static inline void util_est_update(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq,
     /*   */
3989                                    struct task_struct *p,
3990                                    bool task_sleep)
3991 {
3992         long last_ewma_diff, last_enqueued_diff;
3993         struct util_est ue;
3994         int ret = 0;
3995 
3996         trace_android_rvh_util_est_update(cfs_rq, p, task_sleep, &ret);
3997         if (ret)
3998                 return;
3999 
4000         if (!sched_feat(UTIL_EST))
4001                 return;
4002 
4003         /*
4004          * Skip update of task's estimated utilization when the task has not
4005          * yet completed an activation, e.g. being migrated.
4006          */
4007         if (!task_sleep)
4008                 return;
4009 
4010         /*
4011          * If the PELT values haven't changed since enqueue time,
4012          * skip the util_est update.
4013          */
4014         ue = p->se.avg.util_est;
4015         if (ue.enqueued & UTIL_AVG_UNCHANGED)
4016                 return;
4017 
4018         last_enqueued_diff = ue.enqueued;
4019 
4020         /*
4021          * Reset EWMA on utilization increases, the moving average is used only
4022          * to smooth utilization decreases.
4023          */
4024         ue.enqueued = (task_util(p) | UTIL_AVG_UNCHANGED);
4025         if (sched_feat(UTIL_EST_FASTUP)) {
4026                 if (ue.ewma < ue.enqueued) {
4027                         ue.ewma = ue.enqueued;
4028                         goto done;
4029                 }
4030         }
4031 
4032         /*
4033          * Skip update of task's estimated utilization when its members are
4034          * already ~1% close to its last activation value.
4035          */
4036         last_ewma_diff = ue.enqueued - ue.ewma;
4037         last_enqueued_diff -= ue.enqueued;
4038         if (within_margin(last_ewma_diff, UTIL_EST_MARGIN)) {
4039                 if (!within_margin(last_enqueued_diff, UTIL_EST_MARGIN))
4040                         goto done;
4041 
4042                 return;
4043         }
4044 
4045         /*
4046          * To avoid overestimation of actual task utilization, skip updates if
4047          * we cannot grant there is idle time in this CPU.
4048          */
4049         if (task_util(p) > capacity_orig_of(cpu_of(rq_of(cfs_rq))))
4050                 return;
4051 
4052         /*
4053          * Update Task's estimated utilization
4054          *
4055          * When *p completes an activation we can consolidate another sample
4056          * of the task size. This is done by storing the current PELT value
4057          * as ue.enqueued and by using this value to update the Exponential
4058          * Weighted Moving Average (EWMA):
4059          *
4060          *  ewma(t) = w *  task_util(p) + (1-w) * ewma(t-1)
4061          *          = w *  task_util(p) +         ewma(t-1)  - w * ewma(t-1)
4062          *          = w * (task_util(p) -         ewma(t-1)) +     ewma(t-1)
4063          *          = w * (      last_ewma_diff            ) +     ewma(t-1)
4064          *          = w * (last_ewma_diff  +  ewma(t-1) / w)
4065          *
4066          * Where 'w' is the weight of new samples, which is configured to be
4067          * 0.25, thus making w=1/4 ( >>= UTIL_EST_WEIGHT_SHIFT)
4068          */
4069         ue.ewma <<= UTIL_EST_WEIGHT_SHIFT;
4070         ue.ewma  += last_ewma_diff;
