6179 static inline int select_idle_core(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
     /*   */
6180 {
6181         return -1;
6182 }
6183 
6184 static inline int select_idle_smt(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
     /*   */
6185 {
6186         return -1;
6187 }
6188 
6189 #endif /* CONFIG_SCHED_SMT */
6190 
6191 /*
6192  * Scan the LLC domain for idle CPUs; this is dynamically regulated by
6193  * comparing the average scan cost (tracked in sd->avg_scan_cost) against the
6194  * average idle time for this rq (as found in rq->avg_idle).
6195  */
6196 static int select_idle_cpu(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
     /*   */
6197 {
6198         struct cpumask *cpus = this_cpu_cpumask_var_ptr(select_idle_mask);
6199         struct sched_domain *this_sd;
6200         u64 avg_cost, avg_idle;
6201         u64 time;
6202         int this = smp_processor_id();
6203         int cpu, nr = INT_MAX;
6204 
6205         this_sd = rcu_dereference(*this_cpu_ptr(&sd_llc));
6206         if (!this_sd)
6207                 return -1;
6208 
6209         /*
6210          * Due to large variance we need a large fuzz factor; hackbench in
6211          * particularly is sensitive here.
6212          */
6213         avg_idle = this_rq()->avg_idle / 512;
6214         avg_cost = this_sd->avg_scan_cost + 1;
6215 
6216         if (sched_feat(SIS_AVG_CPU) && avg_idle < avg_cost)
6217                 return -1;
6218 
6219         if (sched_feat(SIS_PROP)) {
6220                 u64 span_avg = sd->span_weight * avg_idle;
6221                 if (span_avg > 4*avg_cost)
6222                         nr = div_u64(span_avg, avg_cost);
6223                 else
6224                         nr = 4;
6225         }
6226 
6227         time = cpu_clock(this);
6228 
6229         cpumask_and(cpus, sched_domain_span(sd), p->cpus_ptr);
6230 
6231         for_each_cpu_wrap(cpu, cpus, target) {
6232                 if (!--nr)
6233                         return -1;
6234                 if (available_idle_cpu(cpu) || sched_idle_cpu(cpu))
6235                         break;
6236         }
6237 
6238         time = cpu_clock(this) - time;
6239         update_avg(&this_sd->avg_scan_cost, time);
6240 
6241         return cpu;
6242 }
6243 
6244 /*
6245  * Scan the asym_capacity domain for idle CPUs; pick the first idle one on which
6246  * the task fits. If no CPU is big enough, but there are idle ones, try to
6247  * maximize capacity.
6248  */
6249 static int
6250 select_idle_capacity(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
     /*   */
6251 {
6252         unsigned long task_util, best_cap = 0;
6253         int cpu, best_cpu = -1;
6254         struct cpumask *cpus;
6255 
6256         cpus = this_cpu_cpumask_var_ptr(select_idle_mask);
6257         cpumask_and(cpus, sched_domain_span(sd), p->cpus_ptr);
6258 
6259         task_util = uclamp_task_util(p);
6260 
6261         for_each_cpu_wrap(cpu, cpus, target) {
6262                 unsigned long cpu_cap = capacity_of(cpu);
6263 
6264                 if (!available_idle_cpu(cpu) && !sched_idle_cpu(cpu))
6265                         continue;
6266                 if (fits_capacity(task_util, cpu_cap))
6267                         return cpu;
6268 
6269                 if (cpu_cap > best_cap) {
6270                         best_cap = cpu_cap;
6271                         best_cpu = cpu;
6272                 }
6273         }
6274 
6275         return best_cpu;
6276 }
6277 
6278 static inline bool asym_fits_capacity(int task_util, int cpu)
     /*   */
6279 {
6280         if (static_branch_unlikely(&sched_asym_cpucapacity))
6281                 return fits_capacity(task_util, capacity_of(cpu));
6282 
6283         return true;
6284 }
6285 
6286 /*
6287  * Try and locate an idle core/thread in the LLC cache domain.
6288  */
6289 static int select_idle_sibling(struct task_struct *p, int prev, int target)
     /*   */
6290 {
6291         struct sched_domain *sd;
6292         unsigned long task_util;
6293         int i, recent_used_cpu;
6294 
6295         /*
6296          * On asymmetric system, update task utilization because we will check
6297          * that the task fits with cpu's capacity.
6298          */
6299         if (static_branch_unlikely(&sched_asym_cpucapacity)) {
6300                 sync_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6301                 task_util = uclamp_task_util(p);
6302         }
6303 
6304         if ((available_idle_cpu(target) || sched_idle_cpu(target)) &&
6305             asym_fits_capacity(task_util, target))
6306                 return target;
6307 
6308         /*
6309          * If the previous CPU is cache affine and idle, don't be stupid:
6310          */
6311         if (prev != target && cpus_share_cache(prev, target) &&
6312             (available_idle_cpu(prev) || sched_idle_cpu(prev)) &&
6313             asym_fits_capacity(task_util, prev))
6314                 return prev;
6315 
6316         /*
6317          * Allow a per-cpu kthread to stack with the wakee if the
6318          * kworker thread and the tasks previous CPUs are the same.
6319          * The assumption is that the wakee queued work for the
6320          * per-cpu kthread that is now complete and the wakeup is
6321          * essentially a sync wakeup. An obvious example of this
6322          * pattern is IO completions.
6323          */
6324         if (is_per_cpu_kthread(current) &&
6325             prev == smp_processor_id() &&
6326             this_rq()->nr_running <= 1) {
6327                 return prev;
6328         }
6329 
6330         /* Check a recently used CPU as a potential idle candidate: */
6331         recent_used_cpu = p->recent_used_cpu;
6332         if (recent_used_cpu != prev &&
6333             recent_used_cpu != target &&
6334             cpus_share_cache(recent_used_cpu, target) &&
6335             (available_idle_cpu(recent_used_cpu) || sched_idle_cpu(recent_used_cpu)) &&
6336             cpumask_test_cpu(p->recent_used_cpu, p->cpus_ptr) &&
6337             asym_fits_capacity(task_util, recent_used_cpu)) {
6338                 /*
6339                  * Replace recent_used_cpu with prev as it is a potential
6340                  * candidate for the next wake:
6341                  */
6342                 p->recent_used_cpu = prev;
6343                 return recent_used_cpu;
6344         }
6345 
6346         /*
6347          * For asymmetric CPU capacity systems, our domain of interest is
6348          * sd_asym_cpucapacity rather than sd_llc.
6349          */
6350         if (static_branch_unlikely(&sched_asym_cpucapacity)) {
6351                 sd = rcu_dereference(per_cpu(sd_asym_cpucapacity, target));
6352                 /*
6353                  * On an asymmetric CPU capacity system where an exclusive
6354                  * cpuset defines a symmetric island (i.e. one unique
6355                  * capacity_orig value through the cpuset), the key will be set
6356                  * but the CPUs within that cpuset will not have a domain with
6357                  * SD_ASYM_CPUCAPACITY. These should follow the usual symmetric
6358                  * capacity path.
6359                  */
6360                 if (sd) {
6361                         i = select_idle_capacity(p, sd, target);
6362                         return ((unsigned)i < nr_cpumask_bits) ? i : target;
6363                 }
6364         }
6365 
6366         sd = rcu_dereference(per_cpu(sd_llc, target));
6367         if (!sd)
6368                 return target;
6369 
6370         i = select_idle_core(p, sd, target);
6371         if ((unsigned)i < nr_cpumask_bits)
6372                 return i;
6373 
6374         i = select_idle_cpu(p, sd, target);
6375         if ((unsigned)i < nr_cpumask_bits)
6376                 return i;
6377 
6378         i = select_idle_smt(p, sd, target);
6379         if ((unsigned)i < nr_cpumask_bits)
6380                 return i;
6381 
6382         return target;
6383 }
6384 
6385 /**
6386  * Amount of capacity of a CPU that is (estimated to be) used by CFS tasks
6387  * @cpu: the CPU to get the utilization of
6388  *
6389  * The unit of the return value must be the one of capacity so we can compare
6390  * the utilization with the capacity of the CPU that is available for CFS task
6391  * (ie cpu_capacity).
6392  *
6393  * cfs_rq.avg.util_avg is the sum of running time of runnable tasks plus the
6394  * recent utilization of currently non-runnable tasks on a CPU. It represents
6395  * the amount of utilization of a CPU in the range [0..capacity_orig] where
6396  * capacity_orig is the cpu_capacity available at the highest frequency
6397  * (arch_scale_freq_capacity()).
6398  * The utilization of a CPU converges towards a sum equal to or less than the
6399  * current capacity (capacity_curr <= capacity_orig) of the CPU because it is
6400  * the running time on this CPU scaled by capacity_curr.
6401  *
6402  * The estimated utilization of a CPU is defined to be the maximum between its
6403  * cfs_rq.avg.util_avg and the sum of the estimated utilization of the tasks
6404  * currently RUNNABLE on that CPU.
6405  * This allows to properly represent the expected utilization of a CPU which
6406  * has just got a big task running since a long sleep period. At the same time
6407  * however it preserves the benefits of the "blocked utilization" in
6408  * describing the potential for other tasks waking up on the same CPU.
6409  *
6410  * Nevertheless, cfs_rq.avg.util_avg can be higher than capacity_curr or even
6411  * higher than capacity_orig because of unfortunate rounding in
6412  * cfs.avg.util_avg or just after migrating tasks and new task wakeups until
6413  * the average stabilizes with the new running time. We need to check that the
6414  * utilization stays within the range of [0..capacity_orig] and cap it if
6415  * necessary. Without utilization capping, a group could be seen as overloaded
6416  * (CPU0 utilization at 121% + CPU1 utilization at 80%) whereas CPU1 has 20% of
6417  * available capacity. We allow utilization to overshoot capacity_curr (but not
6418  * capacity_orig) as it useful for predicting the capacity required after task
6419  * migrations (scheduler-driven DVFS).
6420  *
6421  * Return: the (estimated) utilization for the specified CPU
6422  */
6423 static inline unsigned long cpu_util(int cpu)
     /*   */
6424 {
6425         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
6426         unsigned int util;
6427 
6428         cfs_rq = &cpu_rq(cpu)->cfs;
6429         util = READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_avg);
6430 
6431         if (sched_feat(UTIL_EST))
6432                 util = max(util, READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued));
6433 
6434         return min_t(unsigned long, util, capacity_orig_of(cpu));
6435 }
6436 
6437 /*
6438  * cpu_util_without: compute cpu utilization without any contributions from *p
6439  * @cpu: the CPU which utilization is requested
6440  * @p: the task which utilization should be discounted
6441  *
6442  * The utilization of a CPU is defined by the utilization of tasks currently
6443  * enqueued on that CPU as well as tasks which are currently sleeping after an
6444  * execution on that CPU.
6445  *
6446  * This method returns the utilization of the specified CPU by discounting the
6447  * utilization of the specified task, whenever the task is currently
6448  * contributing to the CPU utilization.
6449  */
6450 static unsigned long cpu_util_without(int cpu, struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
6451 {
6452         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
6453         unsigned int util;
6454 
6455         /* Task has no contribution or is new */
6456         if (cpu != task_cpu(p) || !READ_ONCE(p->se.avg.last_update_time))
6457                 return cpu_util(cpu);
6458 
6459         cfs_rq = &cpu_rq(cpu)->cfs;
6460         util = READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_avg);
6461 
6462         /* Discount task's util from CPU's util */
6463         lsub_positive(&util, task_util(p));
6464 
6465         /*
6466          * Covered cases:
6467          *
6468          * a) if *p is the only task sleeping on this CPU, then:
6469          *      cpu_util (== task_util) > util_est (== 0)
6470          *    and thus we return:
6471          *      cpu_util_without = (cpu_util - task_util) = 0
6472          *
6473          * b) if other tasks are SLEEPING on this CPU, which is now exiting
6474          *    IDLE, then:
6475          *      cpu_util >= task_util
6476          *      cpu_util > util_est (== 0)
6477          *    and thus we discount *p's blocked utilization to return:
6478          *      cpu_util_without = (cpu_util - task_util) >= 0
6479          *
6480          * c) if other tasks are RUNNABLE on that CPU and
6481          *      util_est > cpu_util
6482          *    then we use util_est since it returns a more restrictive
6483          *    estimation of the spare capacity on that CPU, by just
6484          *    considering the expected utilization of tasks already
6485          *    runnable on that CPU.
6486          *
6487          * Cases a) and b) are covered by the above code, while case c) is
6488          * covered by the following code when estimated utilization is
6489          * enabled.
6490          */
6491         if (sched_feat(UTIL_EST)) {
6492                 unsigned int estimated =
6493                         READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued);
6494 
6495                 /*
6496                  * Despite the following checks we still have a small window
6497                  * for a possible race, when an execl's select_task_rq_fair()
6498                  * races with LB's detach_task():
6499                  *
6500                  *   detach_task()
6501                  *     p->on_rq = TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING;
6502                  *     ---------------------------------- A
6503                  *     deactivate_task()                   \
6504                  *       dequeue_task()                     + RaceTime
6505                  *         util_est_dequeue()              /
6506                  *     ---------------------------------- B
6507                  *
6508                  * The additional check on "current == p" it's required to
6509                  * properly fix the execl regression and it helps in further
6510                  * reducing the chances for the above race.
6511                  */
6512                 if (unlikely(task_on_rq_queued(p) || current == p))
6513                         lsub_positive(&estimated, _task_util_est(p));
6514 
6515                 util = max(util, estimated);
6516         }
6517 
6518         /*
6519          * Utilization (estimated) can exceed the CPU capacity, thus let's
6520          * clamp to the maximum CPU capacity to ensure consistency with
6521          * the cpu_util call.
6522          */
6523         return min_t(unsigned long, util, capacity_orig_of(cpu));
6524 }
6525 
6526 /*
6527  * Predicts what cpu_util(@cpu) would return if @p was migrated (and enqueued)
6528  * to @dst_cpu.
6529  */
6530 static unsigned long cpu_util_next(int cpu, struct task_struct *p, int dst_cpu)
     /*   */
6531 {
6532         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = &cpu_rq(cpu)->cfs;
6533         unsigned long util_est, util = READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_avg);
6534 
6535         /*
6536          * If @p migrates from @cpu to another, remove its contribution. Or,
6537          * if @p migrates from another CPU to @cpu, add its contribution. In
6538          * the other cases, @cpu is not impacted by the migration, so the
6539          * util_avg should already be correct.
6540          */
6541         if (task_cpu(p) == cpu && dst_cpu != cpu)
6542                 sub_positive(&util, task_util(p));
6543         else if (task_cpu(p) != cpu && dst_cpu == cpu)
6544                 util += task_util(p);
6545 
6546         if (sched_feat(UTIL_EST)) {
6547                 util_est = READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued);
6548 
6549                 /*
6550                  * During wake-up, the task isn't enqueued yet and doesn't
6551                  * appear in the cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued of any rq,
6552                  * so just add it (if needed) to "simulate" what will be
6553                  * cpu_util() after the task has been enqueued.
6554                  */
6555                 if (dst_cpu == cpu)
6556                         util_est += _task_util_est(p);
6557 
6558                 util = max(util, util_est);
6559         }
6560 
6561         return min(util, capacity_orig_of(cpu));
6562 }
6563 
6564 /*
6565  * compute_energy(): Estimates the energy that @pd would consume if @p was
6566  * migrated to @dst_cpu. compute_energy() predicts what will be the utilization
6567  * landscape of @pd's CPUs after the task migration, and uses the Energy Model
6568  * to compute what would be the energy if we decided to actually migrate that
6569  * task.
6570  */
6571 static long
6572 compute_energy(struct task_struct *p, int dst_cpu, struct perf_domain *pd)
     /*   */
6573 {
6574         struct cpumask *pd_mask = perf_domain_span(pd);
6575         unsigned long cpu_cap = arch_scale_cpu_capacity(cpumask_first(pd_mask));
6576         unsigned long max_util = 0, sum_util = 0;
6577         unsigned long energy = 0;
6578         int cpu;
6579 
6580         /*
6581          * The capacity state of CPUs of the current rd can be driven by CPUs
6582          * of another rd if they belong to the same pd. So, account for the
6583          * utilization of these CPUs too by masking pd with cpu_online_mask
6584          * instead of the rd span.
6585          *
6586          * If an entire pd is outside of the current rd, it will not appear in
6587          * its pd list and will not be accounted by compute_energy().
6588          */
6589         for_each_cpu_and(cpu, pd_mask, cpu_online_mask) {
6590                 unsigned long cpu_util, util_cfs = cpu_util_next(cpu, p, dst_cpu);
6591                 struct task_struct *tsk = cpu == dst_cpu ? p : NULL;
6592 
6593                 /*
6594                  * Busy time computation: utilization clamping is not
6595                  * required since the ratio (sum_util / cpu_capacity)
6596                  * is already enough to scale the EM reported power
6597                  * consumption at the (eventually clamped) cpu_capacity.
6598                  */
6599                 sum_util += schedutil_cpu_util(cpu, util_cfs, cpu_cap,
6600                                                ENERGY_UTIL, NULL);
6601 
6602                 /*
6603                  * Performance domain frequency: utilization clamping
6604                  * must be considered since it affects the selection
6605                  * of the performance domain frequency.
6606                  * NOTE: in case RT tasks are running, by default the
6607                  * FREQUENCY_UTIL's utilization can be max OPP.
6608                  */
6609                 cpu_util = schedutil_cpu_util(cpu, util_cfs, cpu_cap,
6610                                               FREQUENCY_UTIL, tsk);
6611                 max_util = max(max_util, cpu_util);
6612         }
6613 
6614         trace_android_vh_em_cpu_energy(pd->em_pd, max_util, sum_util, &energy);
6615         if (!energy)
6616                 energy = em_cpu_energy(pd->em_pd, max_util, sum_util);
6617 
6618         return energy;
6619 }
6620 
6621 /*
6622  * find_energy_efficient_cpu(): Find most energy-efficient target CPU for the
6623  * waking task. find_energy_efficient_cpu() looks for the CPU with maximum
6624  * spare capacity in each performance domain and uses it as a potential
6625  * candidate to execute the task. Then, it uses the Energy Model to figure
6626  * out which of the CPU candidates is the most energy-efficient.
6627  *
6628  * The rationale for this heuristic is as follows. In a performance domain,
6629  * all the most energy efficient CPU candidates (according to the Energy
6630  * Model) are those for which we'll request a low frequency. When there are
6631  * several CPUs for which the frequency request will be the same, we don't
6632  * have enough data to break the tie between them, because the Energy Model
6633  * only includes active power costs. With this model, if we assume that
6634  * frequency requests follow utilization (e.g. using schedutil), the CPU with
6635  * the maximum spare capacity in a performance domain is guaranteed to be among
6636  * the best candidates of the performance domain.
6637  *
6638  * In practice, it could be preferable from an energy standpoint to pack
6639  * small tasks on a CPU in order to let other CPUs go in deeper idle states,
6640  * but that could also hurt our chances to go cluster idle, and we have no
6641  * ways to tell with the current Energy Model if this is actually a good
6642  * idea or not. So, find_energy_efficient_cpu() basically favors
6643  * cluster-packing, and spreading inside a cluster. That should at least be
6644  * a good thing for latency, and this is consistent with the idea that most
6645  * of the energy savings of EAS come from the asymmetry of the system, and
6646  * not so much from breaking the tie between identical CPUs. That's also the
6647  * reason why EAS is enabled in the topology code only for systems where
6648  * SD_ASYM_CPUCAPACITY is set.
6649  *
6650  * NOTE: Forkees are not accepted in the energy-aware wake-up path because
6651  * they don't have any useful utilization data yet and it's not possible to
6652  * forecast their impact on energy consumption. Consequently, they will be
6653  * placed by find_idlest_cpu() on the least loaded CPU, which might turn out
6654  * to be energy-inefficient in some use-cases. The alternative would be to
6655  * bias new tasks towards specific types of CPUs first, or to try to infer
6656  * their util_avg from the parent task, but those heuristics could hurt
6657  * other use-cases too. So, until someone finds a better way to solve this,
6658  * let's keep things simple by re-using the existing slow path.
6659  */
6660 static int find_energy_efficient_cpu(struct task_struct *p, int prev_cpu, int sync)
     /*   */
6661 {
6662         unsigned long prev_delta = ULONG_MAX, best_delta = ULONG_MAX;
6663         struct root_domain *rd = cpu_rq(smp_processor_id())->rd;
6664         int max_spare_cap_cpu_ls = prev_cpu, best_idle_cpu = -1;
6665         unsigned long max_spare_cap_ls = 0, target_cap;
6666         unsigned long cpu_cap, util, base_energy = 0;
6667         bool boosted, latency_sensitive = false;
6668         unsigned int min_exit_lat = UINT_MAX;
6669         int cpu, best_energy_cpu = prev_cpu;
6670         struct cpuidle_state *idle;
6671         struct sched_domain *sd;
6672         struct perf_domain *pd;
6673         int new_cpu = INT_MAX;
6674 
6675         sync_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6676         trace_android_rvh_find_energy_efficient_cpu(p, prev_cpu, sync, &new_cpu);
6677         if (new_cpu != INT_MAX)
6678                 return new_cpu;
6679 
6680         rcu_read_lock();
6681         pd = rcu_dereference(rd->pd);
6682         if (!pd || READ_ONCE(rd->overutilized))
6683                 goto fail;
6684 
6685         cpu = smp_processor_id();
6686         if (sync && cpu_rq(cpu)->nr_running == 1 &&
6687             cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, p->cpus_ptr) &&
6688             task_fits_capacity(p, capacity_of(cpu))) {
6689                 rcu_read_unlock();
6690                 return cpu;
6691         }
6692 
6693         /*
6694          * Energy-aware wake-up happens on the lowest sched_domain starting
6695          * from sd_asym_cpucapacity spanning over this_cpu and prev_cpu.
6696          */
6697         sd = rcu_dereference(*this_cpu_ptr(&sd_asym_cpucapacity));
6698         while (sd && !cpumask_test_cpu(prev_cpu, sched_domain_span(sd)))
6699                 sd = sd->parent;
6700         if (!sd)
6701                 goto fail;
6702 
6703         if (!task_util_est(p))
6704                 goto unlock;
6705 
6706         latency_sensitive = uclamp_latency_sensitive(p);
6707         boosted = uclamp_boosted(p);
6708         target_cap = boosted ? 0 : ULONG_MAX;
6709 
6710         for (; pd; pd = pd->next) {
6711                 unsigned long cur_delta, spare_cap, max_spare_cap = 0;
6712                 unsigned long base_energy_pd;
6713                 int max_spare_cap_cpu = -1;
6714 
6715                 /* Compute the 'base' energy of the pd, without @p */
6716                 base_energy_pd = compute_energy(p, -1, pd);
6717                 base_energy += base_energy_pd;
6718 
6719                 for_each_cpu_and(cpu, perf_domain_span(pd), sched_domain_span(sd)) {
6720                         if (!cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, p->cpus_ptr))
6721                                 continue;
6722 
6723                         util = cpu_util_next(cpu, p, cpu);
6724                         cpu_cap = capacity_of(cpu);
6725                         spare_cap = cpu_cap;
6726                         lsub_positive(&spare_cap, util);
6727 
6728                         /*
6729                          * Skip CPUs that cannot satisfy the capacity request.
6730                          * IOW, placing the task there would make the CPU
6731                          * overutilized. Take uclamp into account to see how
6732                          * much capacity we can get out of the CPU; this is
6733                          * aligned with schedutil_cpu_util().
6734                          */
6735                         util = uclamp_rq_util_with(cpu_rq(cpu), util, p);
6736                         if (!fits_capacity(util, cpu_cap))
6737                                 continue;
6738 
6739                         /* Always use prev_cpu as a candidate. */
6740                         if (!latency_sensitive && cpu == prev_cpu) {
6741                                 prev_delta = compute_energy(p, prev_cpu, pd);
6742                                 prev_delta -= base_energy_pd;
6743                                 best_delta = min(best_delta, prev_delta);
6744                         }
6745 
6746                         /*
6747                          * Find the CPU with the maximum spare capacity in
6748                          * the performance domain
6749                          */
6750                         if (spare_cap > max_spare_cap) {
6751                                 max_spare_cap = spare_cap;
6752                                 max_spare_cap_cpu = cpu;
6753                         }
6754 
6755                         if (!latency_sensitive)
6756                                 continue;
6757 
6758                         if (idle_cpu(cpu)) {
6759                                 cpu_cap = capacity_orig_of(cpu);
6760                                 if (boosted && cpu_cap < target_cap)
6761                                         continue;
6762                                 if (!boosted && cpu_cap > target_cap)
6763                                         continue;
6764                                 idle = idle_get_state(cpu_rq(cpu));
6765                                 if (idle && idle->exit_latency > min_exit_lat &&
6766                                                 cpu_cap == target_cap)
6767                                         continue;
6768 
6769                                 if (idle)
6770                                         min_exit_lat = idle->exit_latency;
6771                                 target_cap = cpu_cap;
6772                                 best_idle_cpu = cpu;
6773                         } else if (spare_cap > max_spare_cap_ls) {
6774                                 max_spare_cap_ls = spare_cap;
6775                                 max_spare_cap_cpu_ls = cpu;
6776                         }
6777                 }
6778 
6779                 /* Evaluate the energy impact of using this CPU. */
6780                 if (!latency_sensitive && max_spare_cap_cpu >= 0 &&
6781                                                 max_spare_cap_cpu != prev_cpu) {
6782                         cur_delta = compute_energy(p, max_spare_cap_cpu, pd);
6783                         cur_delta -= base_energy_pd;
6784                         if (cur_delta < best_delta) {
6785                                 best_delta = cur_delta;
6786                                 best_energy_cpu = max_spare_cap_cpu;
6787                         }
6788                 }
6789         }
6790 unlock:
6791         rcu_read_unlock();
6792 
6793         if (latency_sensitive)
6794                 return best_idle_cpu >= 0 ? best_idle_cpu : max_spare_cap_cpu_ls;
6795 
6796         /*
6797          * Pick the best CPU if prev_cpu cannot be used, or if it saves at
6798          * least 6% of the energy used by prev_cpu.
6799          */
6800         if (prev_delta == ULONG_MAX)
6801                 return best_energy_cpu;
6802 
6803         if ((prev_delta - best_delta) > ((prev_delta + base_energy) >> 4))
6804                 return best_energy_cpu;
6805 
6806         return prev_cpu;
6807 
6808 fail:
6809         rcu_read_unlock();
6810 
6811         return -1;
6812 }
6813 
6814 /*
6815  * select_task_rq_fair: Select target runqueue for the waking task in domains
6816  * that have the 'sd_flag' flag set. In practice, this is SD_BALANCE_WAKE,
6817  * SD_BALANCE_FORK, or SD_BALANCE_EXEC.
6818  *
6819  * Balances load by selecting the idlest CPU in the idlest group, or under
6820  * certain conditions an idle sibling CPU if the domain has SD_WAKE_AFFINE set.
6821  *
6822  * Returns the target CPU number.
6823  *
6824  * preempt must be disabled.
6825  */
6826 static int
6827 select_task_rq_fair(struct task_struct *p, int prev_cpu, int sd_flag, int wake_flags)
     /*   */
6828 {
6829         struct sched_domain *tmp, *sd = NULL;
6830         int cpu = smp_processor_id();
6831         int new_cpu = prev_cpu;
6832         int want_affine = 0;
6833         int sync = (wake_flags & WF_SYNC) && !(current->flags & PF_EXITING);
6834         int target_cpu = -1;
6835 
6836         if (trace_android_rvh_select_task_rq_fair_enabled() &&
6837             !(sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_FORK))
6838                 sync_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6839         trace_android_rvh_select_task_rq_fair(p, prev_cpu, sd_flag,
6840                         wake_flags, &target_cpu);
6841         if (target_cpu >= 0)
6842                 return target_cpu;
6843 
6844         if (sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_WAKE) {
6845                 record_wakee(p);
6846 
6847                 if (sched_energy_enabled()) {
6848                         new_cpu = find_energy_efficient_cpu(p, prev_cpu, sync);
6849                         if (new_cpu >= 0)
6850                                 return new_cpu;
6851                         new_cpu = prev_cpu;
6852                 }
6853 
6854                 want_affine = !wake_wide(p) && cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, p->cpus_ptr);
6855         }
6856 
6857         rcu_read_lock();
6858         for_each_domain(cpu, tmp) {
6859                 /*
6860                  * If both 'cpu' and 'prev_cpu' are part of this domain,
6861                  * cpu is a valid SD_WAKE_AFFINE target.
6862                  */
6863                 if (want_affine && (tmp->flags & SD_WAKE_AFFINE) &&
6864                     cpumask_test_cpu(prev_cpu, sched_domain_span(tmp))) {
6865                         if (cpu != prev_cpu)
6866                                 new_cpu = wake_affine(tmp, p, cpu, prev_cpu, sync);
6867 
6868                         sd = NULL; /* Prefer wake_affine over balance flags */
6869                         break;
6870                 }
6871 
6872                 if (tmp->flags & sd_flag)
6873                         sd = tmp;
6874                 else if (!want_affine)
6875                         break;
6876         }
6877 
6878         if (unlikely(sd)) {
6879                 /* Slow path */
6880                 new_cpu = find_idlest_cpu(sd, p, cpu, prev_cpu, sd_flag);
6881         } else if (sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_WAKE) { /* XXX always ? */
6882                 /* Fast path */
6883 
6884                 new_cpu = select_idle_sibling(p, prev_cpu, new_cpu);
6885 
6886                 if (want_affine)
6887                         current->recent_used_cpu = cpu;
6888         }
6889         rcu_read_unlock();
6890 
6891         return new_cpu;
6892 }
6893 
6894 static void detach_entity_cfs_rq(struct sched_entity *se);
6895 
6896 /*
6897  * Called immediately before a task is migrated to a new CPU; task_cpu(p) and
6898  * cfs_rq_of(p) references at time of call are still valid and identify the
6899  * previous CPU. The caller guarantees p->pi_lock or task_rq(p)->lock is held.
6900  */
6901 static void migrate_task_rq_fair(struct task_struct *p, int new_cpu)
     /*   */
6902 {
6903         /*
6904          * As blocked tasks retain absolute vruntime the migration needs to
6905          * deal with this by subtracting the old and adding the new
6906          * min_vruntime -- the latter is done by enqueue_entity() when placing
6907          * the task on the new runqueue.
6908          */
6909         if (p->state == TASK_WAKING) {
6910                 struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
6911                 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
6912                 u64 min_vruntime;
6913 
6914 #ifndef CONFIG_64BIT
6915                 u64 min_vruntime_copy;
6916 
6917                 do {
6918                         min_vruntime_copy = cfs_rq->min_vruntime_copy;
6919                         smp_rmb();
6920                         min_vruntime = cfs_rq->min_vruntime;
6921                 } while (min_vruntime != min_vruntime_copy);
6922 #else
6923                 min_vruntime = cfs_rq->min_vruntime;
6924 #endif
6925 
6926                 se->vruntime -= min_vruntime;
6927         }
6928 
6929         if (p->on_rq == TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING) {
6930                 /*
6931                  * In case of TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING we in fact hold the 'old'
6932                  * rq->lock and can modify state directly.
6933                  */
6934                 lockdep_assert_held(&task_rq(p)->lock);
6935                 detach_entity_cfs_rq(&p->se);
6936 
6937         } else {
6938                 /*
6939                  * We are supposed to update the task to "current" time, then
6940                  * its up to date and ready to go to new CPU/cfs_rq. But we
6941                  * have difficulty in getting what current time is, so simply
6942                  * throw away the out-of-date time. This will result in the
6943                  * wakee task is less decayed, but giving the wakee more load
6944                  * sounds not bad.
6945                  */
6946                 remove_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6947         }
6948 
6949         /* Tell new CPU we are migrated */
6950         p->se.avg.last_update_time = 0;
6951 
6952         /* We have migrated, no longer consider this task hot */
6953         p->se.exec_start = 0;
6954 
6955         update_scan_period(p, new_cpu);
6956 }
6957 
6958 static void task_dead_fair(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
6959 {
6960         remove_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6961 }
6962 
6963 static int
6964 balance_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev, struct rq_flags *rf)
     /*   */
6965 {
6966         if (rq->nr_running)
6967                 return 1;
6968 
6969         return newidle_balance(rq, rf) != 0;
6970 }
6971 #endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
6972 
6973 static unsigned long wakeup_gran(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
6974 {
6975         unsigned long gran = sysctl_sched_wakeup_granularity;
6976 
6977         /*
6978          * Since its curr running now, convert the gran from real-time
6979          * to virtual-time in his units.
6980          *
6981          * By using 'se' instead of 'curr' we penalize light tasks, so
6982          * they get preempted easier. That is, if 'se' < 'curr' then
6983          * the resulting gran will be larger, therefore penalizing the
6984          * lighter, if otoh 'se' > 'curr' then the resulting gran will
6985          * be smaller, again penalizing the lighter task.
6986          *
6987          * This is especially important for buddies when the leftmost
6988          * task is higher priority than the buddy.
6989          */
6990         return calc_delta_fair(gran, se);
6991 }
6992 
6993 /*
6994  * Should 'se' preempt 'curr'.
6995  *
6996  *             |s1
6997  *        |s2
6998  *   |s3
6999  *         g
7000  *      |<--->|c
7001  *
7002  *  w(c, s1) = -1
7003  *  w(c, s2) =  0
7004  *  w(c, s3) =  1
7005  *
7006  */
7007 static int
7008 wakeup_preempt_entity(struct sched_entity *curr, struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
7009 {
7010         s64 gran, vdiff = curr->vruntime - se->vruntime;
7011 
7012         if (vdiff <= 0)
7013                 return -1;
7014 
7015         gran = wakeup_gran(se);
7016         if (vdiff > gran)
7017                 return 1;
7018 
7019         return 0;
7020 }
7021 
7022 static void set_last_buddy(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
7023 {
7024         if (entity_is_task(se) && unlikely(task_has_idle_policy(task_of(se))))
7025                 return;
7026 
7027         for_each_sched_entity(se) {
7028                 if (SCHED_WARN_ON(!se->on_rq))
7029                         return;
7030                 cfs_rq_of(se)->last = se;
7031         }
7032 }
7033 
7034 static void set_next_buddy(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
7035 {
7036         if (entity_is_task(se) && unlikely(task_has_idle_policy(task_of(se))))
7037                 return;
7038 
7039         for_each_sched_entity(se) {
7040                 if (SCHED_WARN_ON(!se->on_rq))
7041                         return;
7042                 cfs_rq_of(se)->next = se;
7043         }
7044 }
7045 
7046 static void set_skip_buddy(struct sched_entity *se)
     /*   */
7047 {
7048         for_each_sched_entity(se)
7049                 cfs_rq_of(se)->skip = se;
7050 }
7051 
7052 /*
7053  * Preempt the current task with a newly woken task if needed:
7054  */
7055 static void check_preempt_wakeup(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int wake_flags)
     /*   */
7056 {
7057         struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
7058         struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se, *pse = &p->se;
7059         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = task_cfs_rq(curr);
7060         int scale = cfs_rq->nr_running >= sched_nr_latency;
7061         int next_buddy_marked = 0;
7062         bool preempt = false, nopreempt = false;
7063         bool ignore = false;
7064 
7065         if (unlikely(se == pse))
7066                 return;
7067         trace_android_rvh_check_preempt_wakeup_ignore(curr, &ignore);
7068         if (ignore)
7069                 return;
7070 
7071         /*
7072          * This is possible from callers such as attach_tasks(), in which we
7073          * unconditionally check_prempt_curr() after an enqueue (which may have
7074          * lead to a throttle).  This both saves work and prevents false
7075          * next-buddy nomination below.
7076          */
7077         if (unlikely(throttled_hierarchy(cfs_rq_of(pse))))
7078                 return;
7079 
7080         if (sched_feat(NEXT_BUDDY) && scale && !(wake_flags & WF_FORK)) {
7081                 set_next_buddy(pse);
7082                 next_buddy_marked = 1;
7083         }
7084 
7085         /*
7086          * We can come here with TIF_NEED_RESCHED already set from new task
7087          * wake up path.
7088          *
7089          * Note: this also catches the edge-case of curr being in a throttled
7090          * group (e.g. via set_curr_task), since update_curr() (in the
7091          * enqueue of curr) will have resulted in resched being set.  This
7092          * prevents us from potentially nominating it as a false LAST_BUDDY
7093          * below.
7094          */
7095         if (test_tsk_need_resched(curr))
7096                 return;
7097 
7098         /* Idle tasks are by definition preempted by non-idle tasks. */
7099         if (unlikely(task_has_idle_policy(curr)) &&
7100             likely(!task_has_idle_policy(p)))
7101                 goto preempt;
7102 
7103         /*
7104          * Batch and idle tasks do not preempt non-idle tasks (their preemption
7105          * is driven by the tick):
7106          */
7107         if (unlikely(p->policy != SCHED_NORMAL) || !sched_feat(WAKEUP_PREEMPTION))
7108                 return;
7109 
7110         find_matching_se(&se, &pse);
7111         update_curr(cfs_rq_of(se));
7112         trace_android_rvh_check_preempt_wakeup(rq, p, &preempt, &nopreempt,
7113                         wake_flags, se, pse, next_buddy_marked, sysctl_sched_wakeup_granularity);
7114         if (preempt)
7115                 goto preempt;
7116         if (nopreempt)
7117                 return;
7118         BUG_ON(!pse);
7119         if (wakeup_preempt_entity(se, pse) == 1) {
7120                 /*
7121                  * Bias pick_next to pick the sched entity that is
7122                  * triggering this preemption.
7123                  */
7124                 if (!next_buddy_marked)
7125                         set_next_buddy(pse);
7126                 goto preempt;
7127         }
7128 
7129         return;
7130 
7131 preempt:
7132         resched_curr(rq);
7133         /*
7134          * Only set the backward buddy when the current task is still
7135          * on the rq. This can happen when a wakeup gets interleaved
7136          * with schedule on the ->pre_schedule() or idle_balance()
7137          * point, either of which can * drop the rq lock.
7138          *
7139          * Also, during early boot the idle thread is in the fair class,
7140          * for obvious reasons its a bad idea to schedule back to it.
7141          */
7142         if (unlikely(!se->on_rq || curr == rq->idle))
7143                 return;
7144 
7145         if (sched_feat(LAST_BUDDY) && scale && entity_is_task(se))
7146                 set_last_buddy(se);
7147 }
7148 
7149 struct task_struct *
7150 pick_next_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev, struct rq_flags *rf)
     /*   */
7151 {
7152         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = &rq->cfs;
7153         struct sched_entity *se = NULL;
7154         struct task_struct *p = NULL;
7155         int new_tasks;
7156         bool repick = false;
7157 
7158 again:
7159         if (!sched_fair_runnable(rq))
7160                 goto idle;
7161 
7162 #ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
7163         if (!prev || prev->sched_class != &fair_sched_class)
7164                 goto simple;
7165 
7166         /*
7167          * Because of the set_next_buddy() in dequeue_task_fair() it is rather
7168          * likely that a next task is from the same cgroup as the current.
7169          *
7170          * Therefore attempt to avoid putting and setting the entire cgroup
7171          * hierarchy, only change the part that actually changes.
7172          */
7173 
7174         do {
7175                 struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
7176 
7177                 /*
7178                  * Since we got here without doing put_prev_entity() we also
7179                  * have to consider cfs_rq->curr. If it is still a runnable
7180                  * entity, update_curr() will update its vruntime, otherwise
7181                  * forget we've ever seen it.
7182                  */
7183                 if (curr) {
7184                         if (curr->on_rq)
7185                                 update_curr(cfs_rq);
7186                         else
7187                                 curr = NULL;
7188 
7189                         /*
7190                          * This call to check_cfs_rq_runtime() will do the
7191                          * throttle and dequeue its entity in the parent(s).
7192                          * Therefore the nr_running test will indeed
7193                          * be correct.
7194                          */
7195                         if (unlikely(check_cfs_rq_runtime(cfs_rq))) {
7196                                 cfs_rq = &rq->cfs;
7197 
7198                                 if (!cfs_rq->nr_running)
7199                                         goto idle;
7200 
7201                                 goto simple;
7202                         }
7203                 }
7204 
7205                 se = pick_next_entity(cfs_rq, curr);
7206                 cfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
7207         } while (cfs_rq);
7208 
7209         p = task_of(se);
7210         trace_android_rvh_replace_next_task_fair(rq, &p, &se, &repick, false, prev);
7211         /*
7212          * Since we haven't yet done put_prev_entity and if the selected task
7213          * is a different task than we started out with, try and touch the
7214          * least amount of cfs_rqs.
7215          */
7216         if (prev != p) {
7217                 struct sched_entity *pse = &prev->se;
7218 
7219                 while (!(cfs_rq = is_same_group(se, pse))) {
7220                         int se_depth = se->depth;
7221                         int pse_depth = pse->depth;
7222 
7223                         if (se_depth <= pse_depth) {
7224                                 put_prev_entity(cfs_rq_of(pse), pse);
7225                                 pse = parent_entity(pse);
7226                         }
7227                         if (se_depth >= pse_depth) {
7228                                 set_next_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se);
7229                                 se = parent_entity(se);
7230                         }
7231                 }
7232 
7233                 put_prev_entity(cfs_rq, pse);
7234                 set_next_entity(cfs_rq, se);
7235         }
7236 
7237         goto done;
7238 simple:
7239 #endif
7240         if (prev)
7241                 put_prev_task(rq, prev);
7242 
7243         trace_android_rvh_replace_next_task_fair(rq, &p, &se, &repick, true, prev);
7244         if (repick) {
7245                 for_each_sched_entity(se)
7246                         set_next_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se);
7247                 goto done;
7248         }
7249 
7250         do {
7251                 se = pick_next_entity(cfs_rq, NULL);
7252                 set_next_entity(cfs_rq, se);
7253                 cfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
7254         } while (cfs_rq);
7255 
7256         p = task_of(se);
7257 
7258 done: __maybe_unused;
7259 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
7260         /*
7261          * Move the next running task to the front of
7262          * the list, so our cfs_tasks list becomes MRU
7263          * one.
7264          */
7265         list_move(&p->se.group_node, &rq->cfs_tasks);
7266 #endif
7267 
7268         if (hrtick_enabled(rq))
7269                 hrtick_start_fair(rq, p);
7270 
7271         update_misfit_status(p, rq);
7272 
7273         return p;
7274 
7275 idle:
7276         if (!rf)
7277                 return NULL;
7278 
7279         new_tasks = newidle_balance(rq, rf);
7280 
7281         /*
7282          * Because newidle_balance() releases (and re-acquires) rq->lock, it is
7283          * possible for any higher priority task to appear. In that case we
7284          * must re-start the pick_next_entity() loop.
7285          */
7286         if (new_tasks < 0)
7287                 return RETRY_TASK;
7288 
7289         if (new_tasks > 0)
7290                 goto again;
7291 
7292         /*
7293          * rq is about to be idle, check if we need to update the
7294          * lost_idle_time of clock_pelt
7295          */
7296         update_idle_rq_clock_pelt(rq);
7297 
7298         return NULL;
7299 }
7300 
7301 static struct task_struct *__pick_next_task_fair(struct rq *rq)
     /*   */
7302 {
7303         return pick_next_task_fair(rq, NULL, NULL);
7304 }
7305 
7306 /*
7307  * Account for a descheduled task:
7308  */
7309 static void put_prev_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev)
     /*   */
7310 {
7311         struct sched_entity *se = &prev->se;
7312         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
7313 
7314         for_each_sched_entity(se) {
7315                 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
7316                 put_prev_entity(cfs_rq, se);
7317         }
7318 }
7319 
7320 /*
7321  * sched_yield() is very simple
7322  *
7323  * The magic of dealing with the ->skip buddy is in pick_next_entity.
7324  */
7325 static void yield_task_fair(struct rq *rq)
     /*   */
7326 {
7327         struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
7328         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = task_cfs_rq(curr);
7329         struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se;
7330 
7331         /*
7332          * Are we the only task in the tree?
7333          */
7334         if (unlikely(rq->nr_running == 1))
7335                 return;
7336 
7337         clear_buddies(cfs_rq, se);
7338 
7339         if (curr->policy != SCHED_BATCH) {
7340                 update_rq_clock(rq);
7341                 /*
7342                  * Update run-time statistics of the 'current'.
7343                  */
7344                 update_curr(cfs_rq);
7345                 /*
7346                  * Tell update_rq_clock() that we've just updated,
7347                  * so we don't do microscopic update in schedule()
7348                  * and double the fastpath cost.
7349                  */
7350                 rq_clock_skip_update(rq);
7351         }
7352 
7353         set_skip_buddy(se);
7354 }
7355 
7356 static bool yield_to_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
7357 {
7358         struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
7359 
7360         /* throttled hierarchies are not runnable */
7361         if (!se->on_rq || throttled_hierarchy(cfs_rq_of(se)))
7362                 return false;
7363 
7364         /* Tell the scheduler that we'd really like pse to run next. */
7365         set_next_buddy(se);
7366 
7367         yield_task_fair(rq);
7368 
7369         return true;
7370 }
7371 
7372 #ifdef CONFIG_SMP
7373 /**************************************************
7374  * Fair scheduling class load-balancing methods.
7375  *
7376  * BASICS
7377  *
7378  * The purpose of load-balancing is to achieve the same basic fairness the
7379  * per-CPU scheduler provides, namely provide a proportional amount of compute
7380  * time to each task. This is expressed in the following equation:
7381  *
7382  *   W_i,n/P_i == W_j,n/P_j for all i,j                               (1)
7383  *
7384  * Where W_i,n is the n-th weight average for CPU i. The instantaneous weight
7385  * W_i,0 is defined as:
7386  *
7387  *   W_i,0 = \Sum_j w_i,j                                             (2)
7388  *
7389  * Where w_i,j is the weight of the j-th runnable task on CPU i. This weight
7390  * is derived from the nice value as per sched_prio_to_weight[].
7391  *
7392  * The weight average is an exponential decay average of the instantaneous
7393  * weight:
7394  *
7395  *   W'_i,n = (2^n - 1) / 2^n * W_i,n + 1 / 2^n * W_i,0               (3)
7396  *
7397  * C_i is the compute capacity of CPU i, typically it is the
7398  * fraction of 'recent' time available for SCHED_OTHER task execution. But it
7399  * can also include other factors [XXX].
7400  *
7401  * To achieve this balance we define a measure of imbalance which follows
7402  * directly from (1):
7403  *
7404  *   imb_i,j = max{ avg(W/C), W_i/C_i } - min{ avg(W/C), W_j/C_j }    (4)
7405  *
7406  * We them move tasks around to minimize the imbalance. In the continuous
7407  * function space it is obvious this converges, in the discrete case we get
7408  * a few fun cases generally called infeasible weight scenarios.
7409  *
7410  * [XXX expand on:
7411  *     - infeasible weights;
7412  *     - local vs global optima in the discrete case. ]
7413  *
7414  *
7415  * SCHED DOMAINS
7416  *
7417  * In order to solve the imbalance equation (4), and avoid the obvious O(n^2)
7418  * for all i,j solution, we create a tree of CPUs that follows the hardware
7419  * topology where each level pairs two lower groups (or better). This results
7420  * in O(log n) layers. Furthermore we reduce the number of CPUs going up the
7421  * tree to only the first of the previous level and we decrease the frequency
7422  * of load-balance at each level inv. proportional to the number of CPUs in
7423  * the groups.
7424  *
7425  * This yields:
7426  *
7427  *     log_2 n     1     n
7428  *   \Sum       { --- * --- * 2^i } = O(n)                            (5)
7429  *     i = 0      2^i   2^i
7430  *                               `- size of each group
7431  *         |         |     `- number of CPUs doing load-balance
7432  *         |         `- freq
7433  *         `- sum over all levels
7434  *
7435  * Coupled with a limit on how many tasks we can migrate every balance pass,
7436  * this makes (5) the runtime complexity of the balancer.
7437  *
7438  * An important property here is that each CPU is still (indirectly) connected
7439  * to every other CPU in at most O(log n) steps:
7440  *
7441  * The adjacency matrix of the resulting graph is given by:
7442  *
7443  *             log_2 n
7444  *   A_i,j = \Union     (i % 2^k == 0) && i / 2^(k+1) == j / 2^(k+1)  (6)
7445  *             k = 0
7446  *
7447  * And you'll find that:
7448  *
7449  *   A^(log_2 n)_i,j != 0  for all i,j                                (7)
7450  *
7451  * Showing there's indeed a path between every CPU in at most O(log n) steps.
7452  * The task movement gives a factor of O(m), giving a convergence complexity
7453  * of:
7454  *
7455  *   O(nm log n),  n := nr_cpus, m := nr_tasks                        (8)
7456  *
7457  *
7458  * WORK CONSERVING
7459  *
7460  * In order to avoid CPUs going idle while there's still work to do, new idle
7461  * balancing is more aggressive and has the newly idle CPU iterate up the domain
7462  * tree itself instead of relying on other CPUs to bring it work.
7463  *
7464  * This adds some complexity to both (5) and (8) but it reduces the total idle
7465  * time.
7466  *
7467  * [XXX more?]
7468  *
7469  *
7470  * CGROUPS
7471  *
7472  * Cgroups make a horror show out of (2), instead of a simple sum we get:
7473  *
7474  *                                s_k,i
7475  *   W_i,0 = \Sum_j \Prod_k w_k * -----                               (9)
7476  *                                 S_k
7477  *
7478  * Where
7479  *
7480  *   s_k,i = \Sum_j w_i,j,k  and  S_k = \Sum_i s_k,i                 (10)
7481  *
7482  * w_i,j,k is the weight of the j-th runnable task in the k-th cgroup on CPU i.
7483  *
7484  * The big problem is S_k, its a global sum needed to compute a local (W_i)
7485  * property.
7486  *
7487  * [XXX write more on how we solve this.. _after_ merging pjt's patches that
7488  *      rewrite all of this once again.]
7489  */
7490 
7491 unsigned long __read_mostly max_load_balance_interval = HZ/10;
7492 EXPORT_SYMBOL_GPL(max_load_balance_interval);
7493 
7494 enum fbq_type { regular, remote, all };
7495 
7496 /*
7497  * 'group_type' describes the group of CPUs at the moment of load balancing.
7498  *
7499  * The enum is ordered by pulling priority, with the group with lowest priority
7500  * first so the group_type can simply be compared when selecting the busiest
7501  * group. See update_sd_pick_busiest().
7502  */
7503 enum group_type {
7504         /* The group has spare capacity that can be used to run more tasks.  */
7505         group_has_spare = 0,
7506         /*
7507          * The group is fully used and the tasks don't compete for more CPU
7508          * cycles. Nevertheless, some tasks might wait before running.
7509          */
7510         group_fully_busy,
7511         /*
7512          * SD_ASYM_CPUCAPACITY only: One task doesn't fit with CPU's capacity
7513          * and must be migrated to a more powerful CPU.
7514          */
7515         group_misfit_task,
7516         /*
7517          * SD_ASYM_PACKING only: One local CPU with higher capacity is available,
7518          * and the task should be migrated to it instead of running on the
7519          * current CPU.
7520          */
7521         group_asym_packing,
7522         /*
7523          * The tasks' affinity constraints previously prevented the scheduler
7524          * from balancing the load across the system.
7525          */
7526         group_imbalanced,
7527         /*
7528          * The CPU is overloaded and can't provide expected CPU cycles to all
7529          * tasks.
7530          */
7531         group_overloaded
7532 };
7533 
7534 enum migration_type {
7535         migrate_load = 0,
7536         migrate_util,
7537         migrate_task,
7538         migrate_misfit
7539 };
7540 
7541 #define LBF_ALL_PINNED  0x01
7542 #define LBF_NEED_BREAK  0x02
7543 #define LBF_DST_PINNED  0x04
7544 #define LBF_SOME_PINNED 0x08
7545 #define LBF_NOHZ_STATS  0x10
7546 #define LBF_NOHZ_AGAIN  0x20
7547 
7548 struct lb_env {
7549         struct sched_domain     *sd;
7550 
7551         struct rq               *src_rq;
7552         int                     src_cpu;
7553 
7554         int                     dst_cpu;
7555         struct rq               *dst_rq;
7556 
7557         struct cpumask          *dst_grpmask;
7558         int                     new_dst_cpu;
7559         enum cpu_idle_type      idle;
7560         long                    imbalance;
7561         /* The set of CPUs under consideration for load-balancing */
7562         struct cpumask          *cpus;
7563 
7564         unsigned int            flags;
7565 
7566         unsigned int            loop;
7567         unsigned int            loop_break;
7568         unsigned int            loop_max;
7569 
7570         enum fbq_type           fbq_type;
7571         enum migration_type     migration_type;
7572         struct list_head        tasks;
7573         struct rq_flags         *src_rq_rf;
7574 };
7575 
7576 /*
7577  * Is this task likely cache-hot:
7578  */
7579 static int task_hot(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
     /*   */
7580 {
7581         s64 delta;
7582 
7583         lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7584 
7585         if (p->sched_class != &fair_sched_class)
7586                 return 0;
7587 
7588         if (unlikely(task_has_idle_policy(p)))
7589                 return 0;
7590 
7591         /* SMT siblings share cache */
7592         if (env->sd->flags & SD_SHARE_CPUCAPACITY)
7593                 return 0;
7594 
7595         /*
7596          * Buddy candidates are cache hot:
7597          */
7598         if (sched_feat(CACHE_HOT_BUDDY) && env->dst_rq->nr_running &&
7599                         (&p->se == cfs_rq_of(&p->se)->next ||
7600                          &p->se == cfs_rq_of(&p->se)->last))
7601                 return 1;
7602 
7603         if (sysctl_sched_migration_cost == -1)
7604                 return 1;
7605         if (sysctl_sched_migration_cost == 0)
7606                 return 0;
7607 
7608         delta = rq_clock_task(env->src_rq) - p->se.exec_start;
7609 
7610         return delta < (s64)sysctl_sched_migration_cost;
7611 }
7612 
7613 #ifdef CONFIG_NUMA_BALANCING
7614 /*
7615  * Returns 1, if task migration degrades locality
7616  * Returns 0, if task migration improves locality i.e migration preferred.
7617  * Returns -1, if task migration is not affected by locality.
7618  */
7619 static int migrate_degrades_locality(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
     /*   */
7620 {
7621         struct numa_group *numa_group = rcu_dereference(p->numa_group);
7622         unsigned long src_weight, dst_weight;
7623         int src_nid, dst_nid, dist;
7624 
7625         if (!static_branch_likely(&sched_numa_balancing))
7626                 return -1;
7627 
7628         if (!p->numa_faults || !(env->sd->flags & SD_NUMA))
7629                 return -1;
7630 
7631         src_nid = cpu_to_node(env->src_cpu);
7632         dst_nid = cpu_to_node(env->dst_cpu);
7633 
7634         if (src_nid == dst_nid)
7635                 return -1;
7636 
7637         /* Migrating away from the preferred node is always bad. */
7638         if (src_nid == p->numa_preferred_nid) {
7639                 if (env->src_rq->nr_running > env->src_rq->nr_preferred_running)
7640                         return 1;
7641                 else
7642                         return -1;
7643         }
7644 
7645         /* Encourage migration to the preferred node. */
7646         if (dst_nid == p->numa_preferred_nid)
7647                 return 0;
7648 
7649         /* Leaving a core idle is often worse than degrading locality. */
7650         if (env->idle == CPU_IDLE)
7651                 return -1;
7652 
7653         dist = node_distance(src_nid, dst_nid);
7654         if (numa_group) {
7655                 src_weight = group_weight(p, src_nid, dist);
7656                 dst_weight = group_weight(p, dst_nid, dist);
7657         } else {
7658                 src_weight = task_weight(p, src_nid, dist);
7659                 dst_weight = task_weight(p, dst_nid, dist);
7660         }
7661 
7662         return dst_weight < src_weight;
7663 }
7664 
7665 #else
7666 static inline int migrate_degrades_locality(struct task_struct *p,
     /*   */
7667                                              struct lb_env *env)
7668 {
7669         return -1;
7670 }
7671 #endif
7672 
7673 /*
7674  * can_migrate_task - may task p from runqueue rq be migrated to this_cpu?
7675  */
7676 static
7677 int can_migrate_task(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
     /*   */
7678 {
7679         int tsk_cache_hot;
7680         int can_migrate = 1;
7681 
7682         lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7683 
7684         trace_android_rvh_can_migrate_task(p, env->dst_cpu, &can_migrate);
7685         if (!can_migrate)
7686                 return 0;
7687 
7688         /*
7689          * We do not migrate tasks that are:
7690          * 1) throttled_lb_pair, or
7691          * 2) cannot be migrated to this CPU due to cpus_ptr, or
7692          * 3) running (obviously), or
7693          * 4) are cache-hot on their current CPU.
7694          */
7695         if (throttled_lb_pair(task_group(p), env->src_cpu, env->dst_cpu))
7696                 return 0;
7697 
7698         /* Disregard pcpu kthreads; they are where they need to be. */
7699         if ((p->flags & PF_KTHREAD) && kthread_is_per_cpu(p))
7700                 return 0;
7701 
7702         if (!cpumask_test_cpu(env->dst_cpu, p->cpus_ptr)) {
7703                 int cpu;
7704 
7705                 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_failed_migrations_affine);
7706 
7707                 env->flags |= LBF_SOME_PINNED;
7708 
7709                 /*
7710                  * Remember if this task can be migrated to any other CPU in
7711                  * our sched_group. We may want to revisit it if we couldn't
7712                  * meet load balance goals by pulling other tasks on src_cpu.
7713                  *
7714                  * Avoid computing new_dst_cpu for NEWLY_IDLE or if we have
7715                  * already computed one in current iteration.
7716                  */
7717                 if (env->idle == CPU_NEWLY_IDLE || (env->flags & LBF_DST_PINNED))
7718                         return 0;
7719 
7720                 /* Prevent to re-select dst_cpu via env's CPUs: */
7721                 for_each_cpu_and(cpu, env->dst_grpmask, env->cpus) {
7722                         if (cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, p->cpus_ptr)) {
7723                                 env->flags |= LBF_DST_PINNED;
7724                                 env->new_dst_cpu = cpu;
7725                                 break;
7726                         }
7727                 }
7728 
7729                 return 0;
7730         }
7731 
7732         /* Record that we found atleast one task that could run on dst_cpu */
7733         env->flags &= ~LBF_ALL_PINNED;
7734 
7735         if (task_running(env->src_rq, p)) {
7736                 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_failed_migrations_running);
7737                 return 0;
7738         }
7739 
7740         /*
7741          * Aggressive migration if:
7742          * 1) destination numa is preferred
7743          * 2) task is cache cold, or
7744          * 3) too many balance attempts have failed.
7745          */
7746         tsk_cache_hot = migrate_degrades_locality(p, env);
7747         if (tsk_cache_hot == -1)
7748                 tsk_cache_hot = task_hot(p, env);
7749 
7750         if (tsk_cache_hot <= 0 ||
7751             env->sd->nr_balance_failed > env->sd->cache_nice_tries) {
7752                 if (tsk_cache_hot == 1) {
7753                         schedstat_inc(env->sd->lb_hot_gained[env->idle]);
7754                         schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_forced_migrations);
7755                 }
7756                 return 1;
7757         }
7758 
7759         schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_failed_migrations_hot);
7760         return 0;
7761 }
7762 
7763 /*
7764  * detach_task() -- detach the task for the migration specified in env
7765  */
7766 static void detach_task(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
     /*   */
7767 {
7768         int detached = 0;
7769 
7770         lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7771 
7772         /*
7773          * The vendor hook may drop the lock temporarily, so
7774          * pass the rq flags to unpin lock. We expect the
7775          * rq lock to be held after return.
7776          */
7777         trace_android_rvh_migrate_queued_task(env->src_rq, env->src_rq_rf, p,
7778                                               env->dst_cpu, &detached);
7779         if (detached)
7780                 return;
7781 
7782         deactivate_task(env->src_rq, p, DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
7783         set_task_cpu(p, env->dst_cpu);
7784 }
7785 
7786 /*
7787  * detach_one_task() -- tries to dequeue exactly one task from env->src_rq, as
7788  * part of active balancing operations within "domain".
7789  *
7790  * Returns a task if successful and NULL otherwise.
7791  */
7792 static struct task_struct *detach_one_task(struct lb_env *env)
     /*   */
7793 {
7794         struct task_struct *p;
7795 
7796         lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7797 
7798         list_for_each_entry_reverse(p,
7799                         &env->src_rq->cfs_tasks, se.group_node) {
7800                 if (!can_migrate_task(p, env))
7801                         continue;
7802 
7803                 detach_task(p, env);
7804 
7805                 /*
7806                  * Right now, this is only the second place where
7807                  * lb_gained[env->idle] is updated (other is detach_tasks)
7808                  * so we can safely collect stats here rather than
7809                  * inside detach_tasks().
7810                  */
7811                 schedstat_inc(env->sd->lb_gained[env->idle]);
7812                 return p;
7813         }
7814         return NULL;
7815 }
7816 
7817 static const unsigned int sched_nr_migrate_break = 32;
7818 
7819 /*
7820  * detach_tasks() -- tries to detach up to imbalance load/util/tasks from
7821  * busiest_rq, as part of a balancing operation within domain "sd".
7822  *
7823  * Returns number of detached tasks if successful and 0 otherwise.
7824  */
7825 static int detach_tasks(struct lb_env *env)
     /*   */
7826 {
7827         struct list_head *tasks = &env->src_rq->cfs_tasks;
7828         unsigned long util, load;
7829         struct task_struct *p;
7830         int detached = 0;
7831 
7832         lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7833 
7834         if (env->imbalance <= 0)
7835                 return 0;
7836 
7837         while (!list_empty(tasks)) {
7838                 /*
7839                  * We don't want to steal all, otherwise we may be treated likewise,
7840                  * which could at worst lead to a livelock crash.
7841                  */
7842                 if (env->idle != CPU_NOT_IDLE && env->src_rq->nr_running <= 1)
7843                         break;
7844 
7845                 p = list_last_entry(tasks, struct task_struct, se.group_node);
7846 
7847                 env->loop++;
7848                 /* We've more or less seen every task there is, call it quits */
7849                 if (env->loop > env->loop_max)
7850                         break;
7851 
7852                 /* take a breather every nr_migrate tasks */
7853                 if (env->loop > env->loop_break) {
7854                         env->loop_break += sched_nr_migrate_break;
7855                         env->flags |= LBF_NEED_BREAK;
7856                         break;
7857                 }
7858 
7859                 if (!can_migrate_task(p, env))
7860                         goto next;
7861 
7862                 switch (env->migration_type) {
7863                 case migrate_load:
7864                         /*
7865                          * Depending of the number of CPUs and tasks and the
7866                          * cgroup hierarchy, task_h_load() can return a null
7867                          * value. Make sure that env->imbalance decreases
7868                          * otherwise detach_tasks() will stop only after
7869                          * detaching up to loop_max tasks.
7870                          */
7871                         load = max_t(unsigned long, task_h_load(p), 1);
7872 
7873                         if (sched_feat(LB_MIN) &&
7874                             load < 16 && !env->sd->nr_balance_failed)
7875                                 goto next;
7876 
7877                         /*
7878                          * Make sure that we don't migrate too much load.
7879                          * Nevertheless, let relax the constraint if
7880                          * scheduler fails to find a good waiting task to
7881                          * migrate.
7882                          */
7883                         if (shr_bound(load, env->sd->nr_balance_failed) > env->imbalance)
7884                                 goto next;
7885 
7886                         env->imbalance -= load;
7887                         break;
7888 
7889                 case migrate_util:
7890                         util = task_util_est(p);
7891 
7892                         if (util > env->imbalance)
7893                                 goto next;
7894 
7895                         env->imbalance -= util;
7896                         break;
7897 
7898                 case migrate_task:
7899                         env->imbalance--;
7900                         break;
7901 
7902                 case migrate_misfit:
7903                         /* This is not a misfit task */
7904                         if (task_fits_capacity(p, capacity_of(env->src_cpu)))
7905                                 goto next;
7906 
7907                         env->imbalance = 0;
7908                         break;
7909                 }
7910 
7911                 detach_task(p, env);
7912                 list_add(&p->se.group_node, &env->tasks);
7913 
7914                 detached++;
7915 
7916 #ifdef CONFIG_PREEMPTION
7917                 /*
7918                  * NEWIDLE balancing is a source of latency, so preemptible
7919                  * kernels will stop after the first task is detached to minimize
7920                  * the critical section.
7921                  */
7922                 if (env->idle == CPU_NEWLY_IDLE)
7923                         break;
7924 #endif
7925 
7926                 /*
7927                  * We only want to steal up to the prescribed amount of
7928                  * load/util/tasks.
7929                  */
7930                 if (env->imbalance <= 0)
7931                         break;
7932 
7933                 continue;
7934 next:
7935                 list_move(&p->se.group_node, tasks);
7936         }
7937 
7938         /*
7939          * Right now, this is one of only two places we collect this stat
7940          * so we can safely collect detach_one_task() stats here rather
7941          * than inside detach_one_task().
7942          */
7943         schedstat_add(env->sd->lb_gained[env->idle], detached);
7944 
7945         return detached;
7946 }
7947 
7948 /*
7949  * attach_task() -- attach the task detached by detach_task() to its new rq.
7950  */
7951 static void attach_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
7952 {
7953         lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
7954 
7955         BUG_ON(task_rq(p) != rq);
7956         activate_task(rq, p, ENQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
7957         check_preempt_curr(rq, p, 0);
7958 }
7959 
7960 /*
7961  * attach_one_task() -- attaches the task returned from detach_one_task() to
7962  * its new rq.
7963  */
7964 static void attach_one_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
7965 {
7966         struct rq_flags rf;
7967 
7968         rq_lock(rq, &rf);
7969         update_rq_clock(rq);
7970         attach_task(rq, p);
7971         rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
7972 }
7973 
7974 /*
7975  * attach_tasks() -- attaches all tasks detached by detach_tasks() to their
7976  * new rq.
7977  */
7978 static void attach_tasks(struct lb_env *env)
     /*   */
7979 {
7980         struct list_head *tasks = &env->tasks;
7981         struct task_struct *p;
7982         struct rq_flags rf;
7983 
7984         rq_lock(env->dst_rq, &rf);
7985         update_rq_clock(env->dst_rq);
7986 
7987         while (!list_empty(tasks)) {
7988                 p = list_first_entry(tasks, struct task_struct, se.group_node);
7989                 list_del_init(&p->se.group_node);
7990 
7991                 attach_task(env->dst_rq, p);
7992         }
7993 
7994         rq_unlock(env->dst_rq, &rf);
7995 }
7996 
7997 #ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
7998 static inline bool cfs_rq_has_blocked(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
7999 {
8000         if (cfs_rq->avg.load_avg)
8001                 return true;
8002 
8003         if (cfs_rq->avg.util_avg)
8004                 return true;
8005 
8006         return false;
8007 }
8008 
8009 static inline bool others_have_blocked(struct rq *rq)
     /*   */
8010 {
8011         if (READ_ONCE(rq->avg_rt.util_avg))
8012                 return true;
8013 
8014         if (READ_ONCE(rq->avg_dl.util_avg))
8015                 return true;
8016 
8017         if (thermal_load_avg(rq))
8018                 return true;
8019 
8020 #ifdef CONFIG_HAVE_SCHED_AVG_IRQ
8021         if (READ_ONCE(rq->avg_irq.util_avg))
8022                 return true;
8023 #endif
8024 
8025         return false;
8026 }
8027 
8028 static inline void update_blocked_load_status(struct rq *rq, bool has_blocked)
     /*   */
8029 {
8030         rq->last_blocked_load_update_tick = jiffies;
8031 
8032         if (!has_blocked)
8033                 rq->has_blocked_load = 0;
8034 }
8035 #else
8036 static inline bool cfs_rq_has_blocked(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq) { return false; }
     /*   */
8037 static inline bool others_have_blocked(struct rq *rq) { return false; }
     /*   */
8038 static inline void update_blocked_load_status(struct rq *rq, bool has_blocked) {}
     /*   */
8039 #endif
8040 
8041 static bool __update_blocked_others(struct rq *rq, bool *done)
     /*   */
8042 {
8043         const struct sched_class *curr_class;
8044         u64 now = rq_clock_pelt(rq);
8045         unsigned long thermal_pressure;
8046         bool decayed;
8047 
8048         /*
8049          * update_load_avg() can call cpufreq_update_util(). Make sure that RT,
8050          * DL and IRQ signals have been updated before updating CFS.
8051          */
8052         curr_class = rq->curr->sched_class;
8053 
8054         thermal_pressure = arch_scale_thermal_pressure(cpu_of(rq));
8055 
8056         decayed = update_rt_rq_load_avg(now, rq, curr_class == &rt_sched_class) |
8057                   update_dl_rq_load_avg(now, rq, curr_class == &dl_sched_class) |
8058                   update_thermal_load_avg(rq_clock_thermal(rq), rq, thermal_pressure) |
8059                   update_irq_load_avg(rq, 0);
8060 
8061         if (others_have_blocked(rq))
8062                 *done = false;
8063 
8064         return decayed;
8065 }
8066 
8067 #ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
8068 
8069 static inline bool cfs_rq_is_decayed(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
8070 {
8071         if (cfs_rq->load.weight)
8072                 return false;
8073 
8074         if (cfs_rq->avg.load_sum)
8075                 return false;
8076 
8077         if (cfs_rq->avg.util_sum)
8078                 return false;
8079 
8080         if (cfs_rq->avg.runnable_sum)
8081                 return false;
8082 
8083         return true;
8084 }
8085 
8086 static bool __update_blocked_fair(struct rq *rq, bool *done)
     /*   */
8087 {
8088         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, *pos;
8089         bool decayed = false;
8090         int cpu = cpu_of(rq);
8091 
8092         /*
8093          * Iterates the task_group tree in a bottom up fashion, see
8094          * list_add_leaf_cfs_rq() for details.
8095          */
8096         for_each_leaf_cfs_rq_safe(rq, cfs_rq, pos) {
8097                 struct sched_entity *se;
8098 
8099                 if (update_cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq_clock_pelt(cfs_rq), cfs_rq)) {
8100                         update_tg_load_avg(cfs_rq);
8101 
8102                         if (cfs_rq == &rq->cfs)
8103                                 decayed = true;
8104                 }
8105 
8106                 /* Propagate pending load changes to the parent, if any: */
8107                 se = cfs_rq->tg->se[cpu];
8108                 if (se && !skip_blocked_update(se))
8109                         update_load_avg(cfs_rq_of(se), se, 0);
8110 
8111                 /*
8112                  * There can be a lot of idle CPU cgroups.  Don't let fully
8113                  * decayed cfs_rqs linger on the list.
8114                  */
8115                 if (cfs_rq_is_decayed(cfs_rq))
8116                         list_del_leaf_cfs_rq(cfs_rq);
8117 
8118                 /* Don't need periodic decay once load/util_avg are null */
8119                 if (cfs_rq_has_blocked(cfs_rq))
8120                         *done = false;
8121         }
8122 
8123         return decayed;
8124 }
8125 
8126 /*
8127  * Compute the hierarchical load factor for cfs_rq and all its ascendants.
8128  * This needs to be done in a top-down fashion because the load of a child
8129  * group is a fraction of its parents load.
8130  */
8131 static void update_cfs_rq_h_load(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
     /*   */
8132 {
8133         struct rq *rq = rq_of(cfs_rq);
8134         struct sched_entity *se = cfs_rq->tg->se[cpu_of(rq)];
8135         unsigned long now = jiffies;
8136         unsigned long load;
8137 
8138         if (cfs_rq->last_h_load_update == now)
8139                 return;
8140 
8141         WRITE_ONCE(cfs_rq->h_load_next, NULL);
8142         for_each_sched_entity(se) {
8143                 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
8144                 WRITE_ONCE(cfs_rq->h_load_next, se);
8145                 if (cfs_rq->last_h_load_update == now)
8146                         break;
8147         }
8148 
8149         if (!se) {
8150                 cfs_rq->h_load = cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq);
8151                 cfs_rq->last_h_load_update = now;
8152         }
8153 
8154         while ((se = READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->h_load_next)) != NULL) {
8155                 load = cfs_rq->h_load;
8156                 load = div64_ul(load * se->avg.load_avg,
8157                         cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq) + 1);
8158                 cfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
8159                 cfs_rq->h_load = load;
8160                 cfs_rq->last_h_load_update = now;
8161         }
8162 }
8163 
8164 static unsigned long task_h_load(struct task_struct *p)
     /*   */
8165 {
8166         struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = task_cfs_rq(p);
8167 
8168         update_cfs_rq_h_load(cfs_rq);
8169         return div64_ul(p->se.avg.load_avg * cfs_rq->h_load,
8170                         cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq) + 1);
8171 }
8172 #else
8173 static bool __update_blocked_fair(struct rq *rq, bool *done)
     /*   */
8174 {
